Wraþþe gedereþ gret hate,
Loue norisscheþ sauȝtynge.

DIV4.P: ¶ Seruorum ob culpam[Servorum culpa, V. R.] cum te dolor vrget in Iram, Ipse tibi moderare, tuis ut parcere possis.

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif serwe of gult of seruauns
Wol þe bringe in care,
I rede þou tempre þe so wel
Þat tyme þat þou hem spare.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quem superarepotes, interdum uince ferendo; Maxima etenim morum est[Maxima enim morum, V. R.] semper paciencia virtus.

LG.L: Þe mon þat þou maiȝt ouergo,
Wiþ suffrance him ouercome;
Meknes is vertu gret
Wiþ pure riht of dome.

DIV4.P: ¶ Conserua pocius, que sunt iam parta labore: Cum labor in dampno est, crescit mortalis egestas.

LG.L: ¶ Þinges þat þou hast gederet
Wiþ gret bisynesse,
Wysliche þou hem spene,
ffor pereles more and lesse.

DIV4.P: ¶ Dapsilis interdum notis & carus amicis; Cum fueris felix, semper tibi proximus esto.

L.NOTE1: [four English lines omitted: also out of Addit. 22,283.]

DIV4.P: [[Harl. MS. 4657]Telluris si forte u]elis cognoscere cultus, [[Harl. MS. 4657]Virgilium le]gito; quod si mage nosse laboras

LG.L: [Si tu[Addit. 22,283,]] voles sauer,
[Dois ta t]eres cultifier
[Ke] ble ne fayle mye,
¶ Ȝif þou wolt knowe þe tilþe of eorþe,
Þat þe fayle corn none,
Go and red virgiles bok—
Þe craft he tauȝte vchone.

DIV4.P: ¶ Harl. MS. 4657, leaf 40 back, at foot, prefixes this spurious line: 'Humanos si forte uelis depellere morbos;' but MS. Harl. 116, leaf 106 back, of B. Burgh's Cato, has, rightly, only the one line of the text above. Herbarum vires, Macer tibi carmine dicet.

LG.L: Ȝif þou wolt ben a ffisicien,
ffor vueles to ȝiuen bote,
Macer þe strengþe of grases telles,
Boþe of crop and Rote.

DIV4.P: ¶ Si roma[na] cupis & punica noscere bella, Lucanum queras, qui martis prelia dicet.[dixit, V. R.]

L.HI1: Si voil ke tu ne fayles,

LG.L: Ȝif þou wolt knowe þe Batayle
Of Aufrik or of Rome,
Red a Bok þat hette Lucan,
He wol þe telle vchone.

DIV4.P: ¶ Si quid amare libet, uel discere amare legendo, Nasonem petito: [sin autem tibi cura[cura tibi, V. R., and Addit. MS. 22,283.] hec est, (Harl. MS. 116, lf. 107)]

LG.L: Come ly plusours,
Ȝif þou wolt witen of derne loue
And haue þi fflessches wille,
Sech Ouide: he con þe telle
Þe Maners loude and stille.

DIV4.P: ¶ 1Sin autem cura tibi hec est,1[1_1 This belongs metrically to the last couplet, as in Addit. 22, 283: see p. 575.] ut sapiens uiuas, audi, que discere possis.

P.HI1: Per que semotum uiciis deducitur eu[u]m.

L.HI1: E si de cest nas cure,

LG.L: Ȝif þou wolt liue wisliche,
In ȝouþe þi lyf amende;
In þin elde þow maiȝt betere
ffrom vices þe defende.

DIV4.P: ¶ Ergo ades; & que sit sapiencia, disce legendo.

LG.L: . . . . .[English wanting, as in Addit. 22,283.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Si potes, ignotis eciam prodesse memento: Vtilius regno est, meritis adquirere amicos.

LG.L: . . . . .[English wanting, as in Addit. 22,283.]

P.HI1: Mitte archana dei, celum
inquirere quit sit; Cum sis mortalis, que sunt mortalia, cura.

LG.L: ¶ Enquere not of priuites
Of God ne eke of heuene;
Siþen þat þou art dedliche,
Keep þe in þi weies euene.

DIV4.P: ¶ Linque metum leti; nam, stultum est tempore in omni; Dum mortem metuis, amittis[amittere, V. R.] gaudia vite.

LG.L: ¶ fforsak þow þe drede of deþ,
Siþen hit þin Auntur is;
He leoseþ þe Ioye of his lyf
Þat douteþ hit, I-wis.

DIV4.P: ¶ Iratus de re incerta contendere noli: Impedit ira animum, ne possit cernere uerum.

L.HI1: Desturbe, ke il ne seit sage

LG.L: ¶ Striue no þing in þi wraþþe
ffor þing vn-certeyne;
Wraþþe destruyeþ monnes wit,
Whon soþ may not beo seiȝene.

P.HI1: ffac sumptum propere, cum res desiderat ipsa; Dapsilis interdum,
cum tempus postulat aut res.

LG.L: Sum-while spend Mete and drink
Hastiliche, I rede;
Hit falleþ mon to spende his good
Whon tyme hit wole in stede.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quod nimium est, fugito, paruo gaudere memento; Tuta magis[mage est, V. R.] puppis, modico que flumine fertur.

L.HI1: La nef ke veut sor le vnde

LG.L: ¶ To make murþe of luitel þing;
To muche, þou hit fleo;
Schip is more siker in luitel water
Þen in þe deope séé.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quod pudeat, socios prudens celare memento: Ne plures culpent id, quod tibi displicet uni.

LG.L: ¶ Hele þing þat schameþ men,
Qweynte mon ȝif þou beo,
Þat oþer men blame not
Þing þat greueþ þe.[Harl. MS. 4657,]

DIV4.P: ¶ Nolo putes, prauos homines peccata lucrari: Temporibus peccata latent, &[sed, V. R.] tempore parent.

LG.L: [Kar pecche]s escapisent
[E en tens] arere issent
[E renden]t mal louer.
[I nul n]ot þat þou hope
Wicked men sunnes winne;
Sunnes askapen ofte in tounes,
And schewen In tyme and blinne.

P.HI1: Corporis
exigui vires contempnere noli: Consilio pollet, cui uim natura negauit.

LG.L: ¶ Ne haue þou not in dispit
Þe bodi of luitel mon:
In pes and werre þer strengþe is wone,
Good wisdam ofte he con.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quem[Cui, V. R.] scieris non esse parem [te[tibi, Addit. 22,283.] tempore cede: Victorem a uicto superari sepe videmus.

LG.L: ¶ Þouh a mon be not þi peere,
ffor-bere þou him in cas:
Ofte we seon þe strengor falle
Þorw him þat feblore was.

DIV4.P: ¶ Aduersus[MS. Aduersum] notum noli contendere verbis: Lis minimis verbis interdum maxima cressit.

LG.L: ¶ Aȝeines knowen mon ne frend,
Loke þat þou ne striue;
Gret contek of smale wordes
Waxeþ ofte ful ryue.

P.HI1: Quod
deus intendat, noli perquirere sorte; Quod
statuit
de te, sine te deliberat ipse.

L.HI1: Par sort ke deu voyl fere
E tut tei mettes en ly.

LG.L: ¶ Aske not what god wol do
Of þe world bi cas;
Wiþ-outen þe and oþur alle
He mai worche wiþ his gras.

DIV4.P: ¶ Inuidiam nimio cultu uitare memento; Que si non ledat,[ledit, V. R.] tamen hanc sufferre molestum est.

LG.L: ¶ Envye, wiþ gret bisinesse
Beo-þenk þe forte fleo;
Of oþer mennes euel fare,
Envye makeþ him gleo.

DIV4.P: ¶ Esto forti animo,[animo forti, V. R.] cum sis dampnatus inique: Nemo diu gaudet, qui iudice uincit iniquo.

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou be dampned falsliche,
Loke þou beo of wille strong;
No mon Ioyeþ long aftur,
Þat ouer-comeþ wiþ wrong.

DIV4.P: ¶ Litis preterite, noli maledicta referre; Post inimicicias iram meminisse, malorum est.

LG.L: ¶ Of Contek ones forȝiuen,
Reherce no wikkednesse;
Þe wikked mon þe wikked dedes
Recordet, boþe more and lasse.

DIV4.P: ¶ Nec te collaudes, nec te culpaueris ipse: Hoc faciunt stulti, quos gloria vexat inanis.

LG.L: ¶ Preise no mon him-seluen,
Ne blame him-self also;
So don foles, þat veyn glorie
Trauayleþ euer-mo.

DIV4.P: ¶ Vtere quesitis modice: cum sumptus abundat, Labitur exiguo, quod partum est tempore longo.

L.HI1: Kar il est fest en poy detens,

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif and spend a-tempreliche
Þe good þat þou may winne;
Catel is long in gederyng,
And sone a-wei wol renne.

DIV4.P: ¶ Insipiens esto, cum tempus postulat, aut res: Stulticiam simulare loco prudencia summa est.

LG.L: ¶ ffeyne þe fol, þei þou be wys,
Þer fooles aren beo-deene;
A Mon to feynen him on þat wyse
Is wismon, als I wene.

DIV4.P: ¶ Luxuriam fugito, simul & vitare memento Crimen Auaricie; nam sunt contraria fame.

LG.L: ¶ Lecherie and Glotenie,
ffleo hem boþe bi name;
Þei ben two wikked vices,
And bringe men ofte in fame.

DIV4.P: ¶ Noli tu quedam referenti credere semper: Exigua est tribuenda fides, quia multa locuntur.[loquuntur]

LG.L: ¶ Leeue þou not alle mennes tales,
Deceyuet þat þou ne beo;
Mon þat telleþ mony þinges,
ffals most nede sum beo.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quod potu[Quae potus, V. R.] peccas, ignoscere tu tibi noli; Nam nullum crimen uini est, set culpa bibentis.

L.HI1: A tey ne seit il pardone
Kar en le vyn neiȝt il pas
Ne en la coupe le trespas,

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou sunge in drinkyng,
Bi-þenk þe of þat cas;
Þe gult is not in þe ale ne wyn,
But is þyn oune trespas.

DIV4.P: ¶ Concilium archanum tacito committe[MS. committere.] sodali: Corporis auxilium medico committe fideli.

L.HI1: Dyeȝ, e ueyeȝ ke il ne seit volage;

LG.L: ¶ Counseil þer no foly is,
Of þi felawe þou hele;
Put þi body, whon þou art seek,
To leche þat is lele.

DIV4.P: ¶ Successus dignos noli tu[Noli successus indignos, V. R.] ferre moleste: Indulget fortuna malis, ut ledere possit.

LG.L: Tei auygne mal ou perte,

L.HI1: Les maueis, qe ele les greue

LG.L: . . . . . [No English given.][Lines 373-6, p. 584, 'To suffre . . . . .drede,' wrongly follow here in the Vernon MS., and in the Simeon, Addit. MS. 22,283, leaf 121, col. 2.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Prospice, qui ueniunt, hos casus esse ferendo[s]: Nam leuius ledit, quicquid preuidimus ante.

LG.L: ¶ To suffre wo þat is to comen,[Lines 373-6 are a repetition of those on page 583, after no. 97 of the French.]
Porueye þe for nede;
Hap þat we han seiȝen ar þis,
Doþ us more to drede.

DIV4.P: ¶ Rebus in aduersis animum submittere noli; Spem retine: spes una hominem nec morte relinquid.

L.HI1: Quant es al poynt de mort.

LG.L: ¶ Dred no tribulacion,
Þer þou hast þe riht;
Of good hope euer þou be,
And stonde with al þi miht.

DIV4.P: ¶ Rem, tibi quam noscis aptam, dimittere noli; ffronte capillata, post est occasio calua.

L.HI1: Le frount od peil est bel
E par la chef de riers

LG.L: ¶ Profitable þing to þe,
Leeue hit not to ȝare;
Þat forehed is lodly
Þat is calouh and bare.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quod sequitur specta: que quod[specta: quodque, V. R.] imminet ante, videto; Illum imitare deum, partem qui spectat vtramque.

L.HI1: Ke le vn e lautre veyt,

LG.L: ¶ Ende and beginnynge of þi werk
Boþe þou hem bi-holde;
Þulke god folewe bisiliche
Þat alle þing haþ in wolde.

DIV4.P: ¶ fforcius[Fortior, V. R.] ut ualeas, interdum parcior esto: Pauca uoluptati debentur, plura saluti.

LG.L: ¶ Þe hardiore þou holde þi good,
Þe strengore þat þou be;
Mony þing to heleMS. helle. falle,
And fewe to Iolyte.

DIV4.P: ¶ Iudicium populi numquam contempseris vnus: Ne nulli placeas, dum uis contempnere multos.

LG.L: ¶ To Iugement of þe peple
Dispise þou neuere al-one;
He þat dispiseþ mony men,
He is loued of none.

DIV4.P: ¶ Sit tibi precipue, quod primum est, cura salutis; Tempora ne culpes, cum sit[sis, V. R.] tibi causa do[lo]ris.

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þe bi-fallen serwe on honde,
Þe tyme ne blame þou nouht;
God, for vre sunnes alle,
Chaunged werk and þouȝt.

DIV4.P: ¶ Sompnia ne cures; nam mens humana quod optat,[optans, V. R.] Dum vigilat, sperat, per sompnum cernit id Ipsum.

L.HI1: Ce ke il coueit e espeir,

LG.L: ¶ Þing þat þe mette in sweuene,
Telle hit not wakand;
Hit is þing þat þou coueyted
Er longe bi-fore-hand.

DIV4.P: ¶ Hoc quicumque uelis carmen cognoscere lector, Hec precepta feras[Quum p. ferat, V. R.] que sunt gratissima uite,[Commoda multa feres: sin autem spreveris illud, Non me scriptorem, sed te neg|lexeris ipse.]

LG.L: REdere, who-so þat hit be,
Þat þis dite wol knowe,
Þe Comaundement with him bere
And nouȝt to hyȝe ne lowe.

DIV4.P: ¶ Instrue preceptis animum, ne[nec, V. R.] discere cesses; Nam sine doctrina uita est quasi mortis ymago.

LG.L: ¶ fforþure þi wille wiþ wisdam
And sese not for to lere;
Monnes lyf is lyk a ded ymage,
Witles ȝif hit were.

DIV4.P: ¶ Commoda multa feres; sin autem spreueris illud, Non me scriptorem, sed te neglexeris ipsum.

LG.L: Mout aueras profit,

L.HI1: E si tu ne les lyseȝ

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou wolt don aftur me,
Proffyt þou schalt haue;
Ȝif þow wolt dispise me not,
Þin oune worschupe þou saue.

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum recte uiuas, ne cures verba malorum; Arbitrii nostri non est quod quisque loquatur.

L.HI1: Cum vous uiueȝ dreit e ben,
A ceuȝ ke mal vous leyent.

LG.L: ¶ Mekeliche þou suffre chidyng
Of fool oþer of moppe;
Hit is not in vre pouwer
Vche monnes mouþ to stoppe.

DIV4.P: ¶ Productus testis, saluo tamen ante pudore, Quantumcumque potes, celato crimen amici.

LG.L: Quant qi tu purras,
. . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Sermones blandos blesosque cauere memento: Simplicitas veri fama est, fraus ficta loquendi.

LG.L: ¶ Swete wordes of losengri,
Þouȝ þei beo likande,
Eueriche mon ouȝte hem to fle,
And fals hem vnderstande.

DIV4.P: ¶ Segniciem fugito, que uite ignauia fertur; Nam cum animus languet, consumit inercia corpus.

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou ne wolt sleuþe forsake
Wiþ ful gret bisynesse,
Þi lyf is badde, þi bodi sone
Schal falle in seknesse.

DIV4.P: ¶ Interpone tuis interdum gaudia curis, Vt possis animo quemuis sufferre laborem.

L.HI1: De Ioyous estre a la feȝ
Le trauayl ke vous vent sure.

LG.L: ¶ Sum tyme to þi studiing
Þou puit Ioye euere among;
Þou schalt betere afturward
Suffre trauayle strong.

DIV4.P: ¶ Alterius dictum aut factum ne carpseris unquam, Exemplo simuli ne te derideat alter.

LG.L: Ne voylles par nuil plet

L.HI1: Le face en dreyt de cey,

LG.L: ¶ Oþur monnes word ne werk
Loke þat þou ne blame,
Þat he ne mouwe in such a caas
Scorne þe bi þe same.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quod tibi sors dederit tabulis supprema notato, Augendo serua, ne sis, quem fama loquatur.

L.HI1: Ce ke tei chet en sort

LG.L: ¶ Þing þat Aunter haþ þe ȝiuen
Aftur þi frend is ded,
Kep, and saue þi gode los,
And beo I-holden no qued.

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum tibi diuicie superant in fine senecte, Munificus facito uiuas, nec parcus amicis.

L.HI1: Si a la fyn de ta veilesse

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif in þin ende of þin elde
Þe falle richesse strong,
Beo not to scars, freliche dispende
Þer neod is euer among.

DIV4.P: ¶ Vtile consilium dominus ne despice serui; Nullius sensum, si prodest, tempseris vnquam.

L.HI1: Ne lesseȝ le sen de nuly

LG.L: ¶ Dispise no counseil of þi mon,
Ȝif he beo profitable;
Ne þe wit of oþur men,
Ȝif hit beo resonable.

DIV4.P: ¶ Rebus & in censu si non est, quod fuit ante, ffac viuas contentus eo, quod postulat vsus.[q. tempora praebent, V.R.]

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif hit beo not in þi catel
As sum-tyme was bi-fore,
Hold þe payed of þin hap
And haue non herte sore

DIV4.P: ¶ Vxorem fuge ne ducas sub nomine dotis, Nec retinere velis, si ceperit esse molesta.

L.HI1: Pur bien ke seit, mes veies

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Multorum disce exemplo, que facta sequaris, Que fugias; uita est nobis aliena magistra.

LG.L: ¶ Ensaumple tak of mony men
What werkes þe folewe schal;
Þe lyf of oþure goode men
Is Maistres to us alle.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quod potes, id temptes,[tenta, V.R.] operis ne pondere pressus Succumbat labor, & frustra temptata relinquis.

L.HI1: Ke tey ne tut a pres

LG.L: ¶ Þat þou may assaye wel,
I rede, no more, þou bere;
Ȝif þou dost, þou lest þi swik,
And ouer cark wol þe dere.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quod nosti factum non recte, noli silere,[haud recte factum, nolito tacere, V.R.] Ne videare malos imitari uelle tacendo.

LG.L: ¶ Þat þou wost is euel wraþþe,
ffor-hele þou hit nouȝt,
Þat þou suwe no wikked mon
In wille nouþer in þouht.

DIV4.P: ¶ Iudicis auxilium sub iniqua lege rogato; Ipse etiamMS. eniam leges cupiunt, ut iure regantur.

L.HI1: Quant tu veyeȝ ke la ley

LG.L: ¶ Aske to þe help of Iuge,
Vnder wikked lawes;
Þei wol be gouernet al with riht,
Beo nihtes and bi dawes.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quod merito pateris, pacienter ferre memento, Cumque reus tibi[tibi reus, MS.] sis, ipsum te iudice dampna.

LG.L: ¶ Þin harme suffre mildeliche
Þat þou serued wiþ riht,
And þou gulti deme þi-self
And non oþer wiht.

DIV4.P: ¶ Multa legas fac[i]to: perlectis, perlege[neglige, V.R.] multa; Nam miranda canunt, sed non credenda, poete.

LG.L: ¶ Gedere þinges in þin herte
Þat beon to þin biheue;
Þis poete telleþ of merueyles
Þat aren not alle to leue.

DIV4.P: ¶ Inter conuiuas fac sis sermone modesta,[modestus, V.R.] Ne dicare loquax dum vis vrbanus haberi.

L.HI1: Ke tu a get ne seyeȝ

LG.L: ¶ Among þi gistes alle
A-tempre be of word,
Beo corteis and Iangle not
Þer þou art set at bord.

P.HI1: Coniugis irate noli tu uerba timere; Nam lacrimis struit insidias, dum
P.NOTE1: [Nam str. ins. lacr., quum, V. R.]
P.HI1: femina plorat.

LG.L: Quant ta [femme] est yree
¶ Drede not þi wyf whon heo is wroþ,
Mak heo hit neuer so stoute;
Whon heo weopeþ and makeþ deol,
Of hire þenne is more doute.

DIV4.P: ¶ Vtere quesitis, sed ne videaris abuti; Qui sua consumunt, cum deest, aliena secuntur.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

DIV4.P: ¶ ffac tibi proponas, mortem non esse timendam: Que bona si non est, finis tamen illa malorum est.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

P.HI1: Vxoris linguam, si linguam si frugi est, ferre memento; Namque malum [est] nil uelle pati, nil
posse tacere.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

P.HI1: Dilige non ega
caros pietate parentes, Nec matrem offendas dum uis bonus esse parenti.

LG.L: ¶ ffader and moder loke þou loue
Wiþ parfyt herte wiþ-inne;
Loke þat þou ne wraþþe hem nouȝt,
Heore benison to winne.

DIV4.P: ¶ Securam quicumque cupis deducere vitam, Nec uiciis aderre animum, que[haerere animos, qui, V. R.] moribus obsunt.

LG.L: Siker lyf hose wole
In þis world abyde,
put his wylle in gode þewes,
And alle wikked let slyde.

DIV4.P: ¶ Hec precepta tibi semper relegenda memento: Invenies aliquid, quod te vitare magistro.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

P.HI1: Despice diuicias, si uis animo esse beatus; Quas qui suscipiunt, mendicant semper auari.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Comoda nature nullo tibi tempore deerunt, Si contentus eo fueris,[Si fueris c. eo, V. R.] quod postulat vsus.

L.HI1: Pur quei ke sen te dure

LG.L: ¶ Þe propertes of nature
Redi to þe þei be,
Ȝif þou beo payed of þat þing
Þat god haþ sent þe.

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum sis in-cautus, nec racione gubernas, Noli fortunam, que non est, dicere cecam.

L.HI1: E ceo qe as par reson

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou beo no queynte mon
To gouerne þi bailye,
Blame not Aunter afterward,
But wite hit þi folye.

DIV4.P: ¶ Dilige denarium,[denari, V. R.] set parce dilige, formam, Quem nemo sanctus nec honestus captat habere.[ab aere, V. R.]

LG.L: ¶ Loue þe peny for þe nede,
ffor oþer beute non;
Þe holy mon coueiteþ hit not
No more þen a ston.

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum fueris locuples, corpus curare memento; Eger diues habet nummos, set non habet ipsum.

LG.L: ¶ Spene þi tresour, feyne þe not,
Þi bodi for to hele;
What prou may þi catel do,
But hele wol with þe dele?

DIV4.P: ¶ Verbera cum tuleris discens aliquando magistri, ffer patris imper[i]um,[ingenium, V. R.] cum verbis exit in iram.

L.HI1: Ben deis toun pere en Ire

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou haue soffred betyng
Of Maister for þi lore,
Do þi fader comaundement
Boþe lasse and more.

DIV4.P: ¶ Res age, que prosunt: rursus uitare memento, In quibus[quis, V. R.] error inest, nec spes est certa laboris.

LG.L: ¶ Do þing þat þe profite may,
Or helpe þe atte last;
Oþere wikkede errours
A-wei from þe þou cast.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quod donare potes, gratis concede roganti; Nam gratis fecisse bonis, in parte[recte f. b., in parte. V. R.] lucrosum est.

LG.L: ¶ Þat þou maiȝt with rihte ȝef,
To pore þou graunte at nede;
And ȝif þou not þe riche mon,
Þer is no soule mede.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quod tibi suspectum est, confestim discute, quid sit; Namque solent, primo que sunt neglecta, nocere.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum te detineat veneris dampnosa uoluptas, Indulgere gule noli, que ventris amica est.

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou wolt fihte with flessches lust,
Aȝeynes lecherie,
Þou most with-drawe of diuers metes,
And vse no glotenie.

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum tibi preualide fuerint in corpore vires, ffac sapias; quo[sic, V. R.] tu poteris vir fortis haberi.

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou be mon of bodi strong,
Auyse þe wel in þi þouȝt,
Puyt þi strengþe in-to prou,
And elles hit helpeþ þe nouȝt.

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum tibi preponas animalia cuncta timere, Vnum precipio tibi plus hominem[MS. hom. plus.] esse timendum.

LG.L: ¶ Siþen þou art so frele of kuynde
Wilde bestes to doute,
Doute wel more wikked men,
And come not in heore route.

DIV4.P: ¶ Auxilium a notis petito, si forte laboras; Nec quisquam melior medicus, quam fidus amicus.

LG.L: ¶ Aske in trauayle help of frende,
To wisse þe and to rede,
Beter leche knowe I non
Þen trewe frend is at neode.

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum sis ipse nocens, moritur cur uictima pro te? Stulticia in[est, V. R.] mortem alterius sperare salutem.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

P.HI1: Cum tibi uel socium, uel fidum queris amicum, Non fortuna tibi
est hominis, sed vita petenda.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

P.HI1: Vtere quesitis opibus; fuge nomen auari. Quid tibi diuicie prosunt, si
P.NOTE1: [Quo tibi divitias, si semper, V. R.]
P.HI1: pauper abundas?

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Si famam seruare cupis, dum uiuis, honestam, ffac fugias animo, que sunt mala gaudia uite.

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou wolt kepe þi gode loos
ffrom wiked sunne and blame,
To veyne ioyes of þis world
ffor-sak hem alle bi name.

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum sapias animo, noli irridere senectam; Nam quocumque sene,[quicumque senet, V. R.] puerilis sensus in illo est.

LG.L: ¶ In old mon is childes wit,
Soþ þou schalt hit fynde;
Ȝif þou be wys, scorn him not,
Hit falleþ to his kuynde.

DIV4.P: ¶ Disce aliquid; nam, cum subito fortuna recedit,[recessit, V. R.] Ars remanet uitamque hominis non deserit vnquam.

LG.L: ¶ Leorn sum good, whil þou miht;
Auenture haþ no make;
Mester wol not fayle þi lyf,
Hit nul þe neuere forsake.

DIV4.P: ¶ Prospicito cuncta[Perspicito tecum, V. R.] tacitus, quod quisque loquatur: Sermo hominum mores celat, set & indicat idem.

L.HI1: Kar la parole a plusours hommes

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

P.HI1: Exerce studium, quam-uis perceperis artem: Vt cura ingenium, quoque sic
manus adiuat usum.

L.HI1: Ia seit I ceo ke tu as

LG.L: Haunte studie, þauȝ þou haue
Wel conceyued þi craft,
Þat wille and wit and þin hond
To-gedere ben i-laft.

DIV4.P: ¶ Multum uenturi ne cures tempora fati: Non metuit mortem qui s[c]it contempnere uitam.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

P.HI1: Disce, set a doctis: indoctos ipse doceto; propaganda est etenim
rerum doctrina bonarum.

LG.L: ¶ Heeren þou schalt of wyse men;
And loke wel in þi mood
Þi wit to spene wysliche,
And eke þin oþer good.

DIV4.P: ¶ Hoc bibe quod possis, si tu uis viuere sanus: Morbi namque mali causa[M. causa mali nimia, V. R.] est quecumque voluptas.

LG.L: ¶ Drink þat þou beo meþful,
And lyue in hele good;
ffoul delyt in drunkennesse
Makeþ men ofte ful wood.

DIV4.P: ¶ Laudaris quodcumque palam, quecumque probaris, Prospice,[Hoc vide, V. R.] ne rursus leuitatis crimine dampnes.

LG.L: ¶ Þing þat þou hast ones preised
Be-fore þe folk ouer al,
Blame hit not þer-afturward,
Beo hit gret or smal.

DIV4.P: ¶ Tranquillis rebus, que su[n]t aduersa caueto:[timeto, V. R.] Rursus in aduersis, melius sperare memento

LG.L: ¶ In þi weolþe þou þenk of wo,
So maiȝt þou þe meke;
In wo also haue hope of helpe,
So maist þou cumforte þe seke.

P.HI1: [Discere ne cesses: cura sapientia crescit: Rara datur longo prudentia temporis usu.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Parce laudato; nam, quem tu sepe probaris, Vna dies, qualis fuerit, demonstrat,[ostendet, V. R.] amicus.

LG.L: Mesurablement

L.HI1: Kar vn Iour ver tei fra

LG.L: ¶ Preise a mon so scarsliche,
Whom þat þou wolt him proue;
He schal sum tyme schewe openliche
Wher he þe hate or loue.

DIV4.P: ¶ Ne pudiat, que nescieris, te uelle doceri: Scire aliquid laus est; turpe[culpa, V. R.] est, nil discere uelle.

LG.L: ¶ Þat þou ne const, schome þe not
Of oþere to ben I-tauht;
He þat nout con, ne nout wol lerne,
May neuer ben I-sauȝt.

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum uenere & bacho lis est, coniuncta[sed iuncta, V. R.] voluptas. Quod lautum est, animo complectere, set fuge lites.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Dimissos animo tacitos que cauere[ac tacitos vitare, V.R.] memento: Quo[Qua, V.R. flumen placidum est, forsan latet alciori[altius, V.R.] vnda.

LG.L: Kar il auent ke lounde,
¶ In vche stude, in vche tyme,
Þe stille mon þou drede and fle;
Þer water is most deope,
Þe lasse þer þen steres he.

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum tibi displiciat rerum fortuna tuarum, Alter[i]us specta, quo sis discrimine peior.

L.HI1: Ou vice en quey ceo pecche,

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif auenture nul not þe serue
As he doþ oþer men,
Bi-hold þi tecches or þi sunne,
Wher þou beo gulti þen.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quod potes, id tempta: litus nam[nam litus, V.R.] carpere remis Tucius est multo, quam uelum tendere in altum.

LG.L: Aȝeyn þe strem ne striue þou nouȝt,
Ne nuiȝe þe not wiþ wrong;
ffor eueri werk wronglich wrouht
God wol venge a-mong.

DIV4.P: ¶ Contra hominem iustum praue contendere noli: Sepe[Semper, V.R.] enim deus iniustas vlciscitur iras.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Ereptis opibus, noli tu flere[maerere, V.R.] dolendo: Set gaude pocius, si te contingat[tibi si contingit, V.R.] habere.

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou leosest þi worldes good,
To gret deol mak þou nouȝt,
Raþer, ȝif þe fayle þe chaunce,
Haue Ioye in þi þouȝt.

DIV4.P: ¶ Est iactura grauis, que sunt, amittere dampnis: Sunt quedam, que ferre decet pacienter amicum.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Tempora longa tibi noli promittere vite: Quocumque ingrederis, sequitur mors, corporis vmbram.

L.HI1: Ou ke vnkes uas eyns ou hors,

LG.L: ¶ Haue non hope to liuen longe,
But diht þe euere on hiȝe;
Wher-so þou gost, niht or day,
Þi deþ foleweþ þe neihe.

DIV4.P: ¶ Ture deum placa: vitulum sine crescat aratro; Ne credas placare deum, cum cede litatur.

L.HI1: Ke dieu de ceo seit leȝ

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Cede locum lesis fortune,[laesus Fortunae, V.R.] cede potenti; Ledere qui poterit, prodesse aliquando valebit.

L.HI1: Quant il fet mal a tey;

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou stude to grete men,
Þauh ofte þei greueþ þe;
Oþer-tyme þei may þe profyte—
And her-of loke þou leeue me.

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum tu[Quum quid, V.R.] peccaris, castiga te ipse subinde: Vulnera dum sanas, dolor est medicina doloris.

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou sum tyme dost a sunne,
Sone þou hit amende;
Serwe is medicine of þi gult,
And God is wonder hende.

DIV4.P: ¶ Dampnaris nunquam post longum tempus amicum; Mutauit mores: sed pignora prima memento.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Gracior officijs, quo sis mage carior, esto: Ne nomen subeas, quod dicitur, officij perdi.[officiperdi, V.R.]

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou beo holden deore with frend,
Him þou serue þe more to gre,
Þat wikked reson bi good enchesun
Beo not put on þe.

DIV4.P: ¶ Suspectus caueas, ne sis miser omnibus horis: Nam timidis & suspectis aptissima mors est.

LG.L: . . . . . [English wanting, space left.]

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum seruos fueris proprios mercatus in vsus Et famulos dicas, homines tamen esse memento.

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif þou haue seruauns mony on,
To werk and don vsage,
Beo-þenk þe wel þat þei beo men
And lyk to þin ymage.

DIV4.P: ¶ Quam primum rapienda tibi est occacio prima: Ne rursus queras, que iam neglexeris ante.

LG.L: ¶ Tak what þing þe profred is
Whon þou maiȝt redi haue;
He þat nul not whon he may,
Ofte haþ not whon he wol craue.

DIV4.P: ¶ Morte repentina noli gaudere malorum: ffelices obeunt, quorum sine crimine uita est.

LG.L: ¶ Of sodeyn deþ of wikked men
Ioye ne make þou none;
Holy men and of lyue clene
Diden so als maiȝt þou done.

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum coniux tibi sit, nec[Quum tibi fit conjux, ne, V.R.] res & fama laborat, Vita ne[Vitandum, V.R.] ducas inimicum nomen amici.

LG.L: ¶ Ȝif men tellen harm bi þi wyf
Or oþer ffrend beo name,
Til hit beo proued, leeue hit nouȝt;
Empeyre þou nouȝt hire fame.

DIV4.P: ¶ Cum tibi contigerit studio cognoscere multa, ffac discas multa; culpa est nil velle[et vita nescire, D.] doceri.

LG.L: ¶ Þouh þat þou knowe fele þinges
Be studie and bi lore,
Let not o Bok, bisiliche
Beo lernynge euer-more.
¶ Coueyte not to muche good,
And do aftur my red;
Þe ouerdon gredi mon
Beggeþ ofte his bred.G. E. Weber says, in Corpus Poet. Latin., 1833, p. 1198: 'Additur denique distichon satis ineptum: Miraris verbis nudis,' &c. The Various Readings above are from his text.

DIV4.P: ¶ Mireris verbis nudis me scribere versus? Hos breuitas sensus fecit congungere[coniungere, V.R.] binos.

L.HI1: Ke ieo ay ces vers escrit

LG.L: ¶ Þe merueyles of þise nakede vers
Beoþ maked bi two and two:
Þe schortnesse of my luitel wit
Dude me en-Ioynen hem so.
¶ Wise men may a-mende þis ieste,
And resouns puten and eche:
Þo þat reden on þis bok,
Þerof I hem biseche.
¶ Alle þat reden and wolle recorden
Þis smale techinges bi-dene,
God hem graunte, þorw his grace,
Of heore sunnes be clene. Amen!

DIV2.HEAD: LI. The Stacions of Rome. [The Prolog only.]

LG.L: LOrd Ihesu crist In Trinite,
Þreo persones In vnite,
Þat on God is in makynge,
Þat is and was of alle þinge,
Seende us grace now so biginne,
Þat we mowe so heuene winne,
Þat mowe we not don here,
Bot ur soules ben of sunne clere.
Hose wot his soule In synne bounde,
I wol him techen In a stounde,
Where he may medicyn fynde
His soule of sunne to vnbynde,
And from pyne him saue sikerly,
Þat in þe fuir of helle is redy;
And also from þe fuir of helle,
Wher-of þe peynes no mon con telle.
¶ To grete Rome gon he mote,
Þer is þe Medicyn, crop and Rote,
Þat men clepeþ pardoun.
Ȝonge and Olde in eueri toun,
Þer is forsoþe welle of grace
To alle þat visyteþ þat place,
And ben in loue and charite
Touward vche mon what so he be,
And kepeþ him clene to his ende,
Nedes to heuene moste he wende
Wiþ-outen peyne lasse or more,
His soule to dwellen euere þore.
Þat may vche mon at Rome fynde,
And clene his soule of synne vnbynde,
As I her-after ow schal telle.
In diuerse churches, and ȝe wol dwelle,
An holy lyf is in þat place,
Men may hit leeue, hose haþ grace.
Seouen hundret and fifti ȝer be-foren
Þat vr lord Ihesu was boren,
Two knihtes come from troye
In-to Itayle with muchel Ioye,
Is cleped Remous and Romilus,
As olde Cronycles telleþ þus.
Þei weoren breþeren of muchel miht,
And muchel douted in fiht,
And foundeours of Rome, þat grete citéé,
Þat is ful of grace and dignite,
And cleped is Rome after hem,
As cronicles telleþ alle men.
Al was heþene þat was þer-Inne,
fful of wikkednes and of sinne,
Til peter and poul, and seynt Ion,
And oþer holye mony on,
Þider come wiþ godes miht
To cristene þe peple day and niht,
To teche hem cristes lore,
Boþe þe lasse and eke þe more.
Þer weore þei mony a gret stounde,
So harde in meschef and sunne I-bounde,
Þat cristendam ne wolden take,
Ne heore Maumetrie forsake;
And slowen Peter and poul also,
And oþer seintes mony mo:
Mony Miracle of hem gon falle
In þe Cite of þe heiȝe halle,
Of þe Martires þat þei hedde made,
Þat coude no better rade,
And cristned bi-comen mony one
Of heþene men þat weren in Rome.
Þe moredel þat weore þer-inne,
And also al þat þei mihte winne.
¶ And þo þat wolde not cristned be,
Weore he bonde, weore he fre,
To deþe anon was he don,
Moste þer no gold for him gon;
In-to Rome þus com cristendom,
And for vr alre sauacion.
¶ Now þis schal beo þe parclose,
No more to speken of þis prose,
But of holynesse and dignite,
Graunted in chirches of þat cite.

HOse wole his soule leche . . . . .[The rest of the poem, after 1. 78, is printed in No. 25 of the E. E. Text Society's Original Series, 1867, pages 1-24, and is therefore not repeated here. Had I recollected that the next poem—the 'Disputation'—had been printed by our late lamented friend, Dr. Richard Morris, in his Legends of the Holy Rood, E. E. T. Soc., 1871, p. 131-149, and (from the Royal MS. 18, A 10) p. 197-209, it would not have found place here; but I'd forgotten all about it till the revise came, and therefore do not cancel it.— F., 14 June, 1894.]

DIV2.HEAD: LII. Disputation between Mary and the Cross.
DIV2.P: [40 Alliterative Stanzas: nos. 1 and 40, either nine lines with 2 central rymes, aaaa, bcccb; or 17 lines, aab, aab, aab, aab, cdddc; nos. 2-39, thirteen lines abab, abab, cdddc.]

LG.L: Oure ladi freo, on Rode treo, made hire mon:
Heo seid, "on þe, þe fruit of me, is wo bigon;
Mi fruit I seo, in blodi bleo, among his fon;
Serwe I seo, þe veines fleo, from blodi bon.These 4 lines might each be set in 4 threes, aab, as those in stanza 40 (p. 626) are in the MS, the printed below as single lines.
Cros, þou dost no trouþe,
On a pillori my fruit to pinne.
He haþ no spot of Adam sinne:
fflesch and veines nou fleo a-twinne;
Wherfore I rede of routhe.
Cros, þi bondes schul ben blamed,
Mi fayre fruit þou hast bi-gyled,
Þe fruites Mooder was neuere a-famed,
Mi wombe is feir, founden vn-fuyled.
Chyld, whi artou not a-schamed
On a pillori to ben I-piled?
Grete Iewes þus weore gramed,
And dyede for heore werkes wyled.
In mournyng I may melte;
Mi fruit þat is so holi halwed,
In a feeld is fouled and falwed;
Wiþ grete Iewes he is galwed,
And dyeþ for Monnes gelte.
FOr grete Iewes, galwes weire greiþed,
Þat euer to Robbyng Ronne ryf.
Whi schal my sone on þe beo leid,
Þat neuer nuyȝed mon nor wyf?
A drinke of deþ, soþliche seid,
Cros, þou ȝeuest þe lord of lyf,
His veynes to-bursten wiþ þi breid.
Mi fruit stont nou in a strong stryf;
Blod from hed is hayled;
ffouled is my fayre fruit,
Þat neuer dude tripet ne truit.
Wiþ þeues þat loueden ryot and ruit,
Whi schal my sone be nayled?
Þoruȝ Iugement þou art en-Ioynet
To bere fooles ful of sinne.
Mi sone from þe schulde beon ensoynet,
And neuere his blod vppon þe rinne;
But nou is truþe wiþ tresun teynet,
Wiþ þeoues to honge fer in fenne;
Wiþ feole nayles his limes ben feynet;
A careful Moder men mai me kenne;
In Bales I am bounde.
Þat fruit was of a Mayden born,
On a þeoues tre is al to-torn.
A Broche þorw-out his brest [is] born,
His holi herte haþ wounde.
Tre! þou art loked bi þe lawe,
Þeoues, traitours, on þe to dye;[? deye]
But now is trouþe wiþ tresun drawe,
And vertu falleþ in vices weye;
But loue and treuþe in soþfast sawe
On a treo traytours hem teye;
Vertu is wiþ vices slawe.
Of alle vertues my sone is keye,
Vertu swettore þen spices;
In fot and hond bereþ blodi prikke,
His hed is ful of þornes þikke;
Þe goode hongeþ a-mong þe wikke;
Vertu dyeþ wiþ vices.
Tre vnkynde, þou schalt be kud;
Mi sone step-Moder, I þe calle.
Mi fruit was born wiþ beestes on bed,
And be my flesch my flour gan falle.
Wiþ my brestes, my brid I fed;
Cros! þou ȝeuest him Eysel and Galle.
Mi white Rose Red is spred,
Þat fostred was in a fodderes stalle.
ffeet and fayre hondes
Þat nou ben croised, I custe hem ofte;
I lulled hem, I leid hem softe.
Cros! þou holdest hem hiȝe on lofte,
Bounden in bledyng bondes.
Mi loue i-lolled vp in þe eyr,
Wiþ cradel bond I gan him bynde.
Cros! he stikeþ nou on þi steir,
Naked a-ȝeyn þe wylde wynde.
ffoules fourmen heor nestes in þe eyr;
Wolues, in den, reste þei fynde;
Bot Godes sone, in heuene heir,
His hed nou leoneþ on þornes tynde.
Of mournyng I may mynne:
Godes hed haþ reste non,
But leoneþ on his scholder bon;
Þe þornes þorwh his flesch[e] gon;
His wo I wytte hit sinne.
Cros! to slen, hit is þi sleiht;
Mi fayre fruit þou berest fro blis.
Cros! þou holdest him so heih on heiȝþ,
Mi fruites feet I mai not kis.
Mi mouþ I pulte, my sweore I streiȝt
To cusse his feet, soþ þing hit is.
Þe Iewes from þe cros me keiȝt;
On me þei made heore mouwes amis,
Heore games and heore gaudes;
Þe Iewes wrouȝten me ful wo.
Cros! I fynde þou art my fo.
Þou berest my brid beten blo,
Among þeose fooles fraudes."
Cristes cros ȝaf onswere:
"Ladi, to þe I owe honour;
Þi brihte palmes nou I bere;
Mi schyning scheweþ þorw þi flour;
Þi feire fruit on me ginneþ tere;
Þi fruit me florischeþ in blod colour.
To winne þe world þat lay in lere,[MS. lure]
Þat Blosme Blomed vp in þi bour,
Ac not for þe al-one,
But for to winne al þis werld
Þat swelte vndur þe deueles swerd;
Þorw feet and hond God let him gerd,
To a-mende monnes mone.
Adam dude ful huge harmes
Whon he bot a bite vndur a bouh;
Wherfore þi sone haþ sprad his Armes
On a treo tyed wiþ teone I-nouh.
His flesch is smite wiþ deþes þarmes,
And swelteþ heer in a swemly swouh.
His Breste is bored wiþ deþes swarmes;
And wiþ his deþ, fro deþ he drouh
Alle his leoue freondes,
As Oȝie spac in prophecie;
And seide, 'þi sone, seinte Marie,
His deþ slouȝ deþ on Caluarie,
Ȝaf lyf wiþ-outen endes.'
Þe stipre[? MS. scipre] þat is vnder þe vyne set,
May not bringe forþ þe grape;
Þeih þe fruit on meþ[? for me] beo knet,
His scharpe schour haue I not schape.
Til grapes to þe presse beo set,
Þer renneþ no red wyn in rape;
Neuere presse pressed bet.
I presse wyn for kniht and knape,
Vp-on a Blodi brinke.
I presse a grape with strok and stryf;
Þe Rede wyn renneþ ryf;
In Samaritane, God ȝaf a wyf
Þat leof licour to drinke.
LAdi! loue doþ þe to alegge!
Þi fruit is prikked wiþ speres ord;
On Cros, wiþ-outen knyues egge,
I kerue fruit of godes hord:
Al is al red, Rib and Rugge;
His bodi bledeþ aȝeyn þe bord;
I was piler and bar a brugge;
God is weie, witnesse of word,
God seiþ he is soþfast weye.
Mony folk slod to helle slider;
To heuene, mihte no mon þider,
Til god dyed, and tauȝte whider
Men drawen whon þei dye.
Moyses haþ fourmed in his figour,
A whit lomb, and non oþer beste,
Schulde be sacred vr saueour,
And be mete of mihtes meste.
I was þat cheef chargeour;
I bar flesch for folkes feste,
Ihesu crist vre saueour,
He fedeþ boþe lest and meste;
Rosted a-ȝeyn þe sonne,
On me lay þe lomb of loue;
I was plater, his bodi a-boue;
Til feet and hondes al to-cloue,
Wiþ blood I was bi-ronne.
Ȝit Moyses in Rule haþ rad,
We schulde ete vr lomb in sour vergeous;
Sour vergeous mai make vr soules glad,
To serwe sore for sunnes ours.
Sour vergeous schal make þe deuel adrad,
ffor he fleccheþ fro godes spous.
Beo a staf stondeþ sad,
Whon ȝe fongen flesch in godes hous.
Þat staf is Cristes Crouche;
Stondeþ stifli bi þat stake,
Whon þat ȝe fongen flesch in Cake;
Þen schal no feond maystri make,
Ȝoure soules for to touche.
For pardoun scheweþ be a shrine:
Wiþ nayl and brede, on bord is smite
Rede lettres write be lyne,
Bluwe, Blake, among men pite.
Vr lord I likne to þis signe:
His bodi vppon a bord was bite;
In Briht[e] blod, his bodi gan schyne:
Hou wo him was, may no mon wite,
Red vp on þe Roode.
Vr pardoun, brede from top too to,
Writen hit was wiþ wonder wo;
Wiþ Rede woundes and strokes blo,
Vre Book was bounden in bloode.
Adam stod vp in stede;
In Bitter galle, his gost he dreint:
A-ȝeyn þat galle, God ȝaf vs mede;
Wiþ swete Merci, Bitter is queynt.
His Bodi was Book, þe Cros was brede,
Whon Crist for vs þeron was cleynt.[or weynt]
No mon gat pardoun wiþ no bede,
Weor he neuere so sely a seynt,
Til book on bord was sprad,
Wiþ sharpe nayles dunted and driue,
Til feet and hondes al to-riue;
His herte blod, vre book haþ ȝiue,
To make vr gostes glad."
Cristes Cros ȝit spac þis speche:
"ffurst was I presse, wyn to wringe;
I bere a Brugge, wei to teche,
Þer semely Aungeles sitte and synge.
Lord of loue and lyues leche,
ffor þe was set sely sacrynge;
To winne þe world þat was in wreche,
Þe cros was brede, pardoun to bringe.
Pardoun In book is billed:
What is pardoun, vppon to minne?
Hit is forȝiuenes of dedly sinne:
Whon blod was writen on cristes kinne,
Pardoun was fulfilled."
Oure ladi seide, "Cros! of þi werk,
Wonder þe not, þeiȝ I be wroþe.
Þus seide Poule, Cristes clerk:
Þe feolle Iewes, wiþ false oþe,
Iewes ston-hard in sinnes merk,
Beoten a lomb wiþ-outen loþe,
Softer þen watur vndur serk,
Meode or Milk [i-]medled boþe.
Þe Iewes weoren harde stones:
Softur þen watur or eny licour,
Or dewȝ þat liþ on þe lilie flour,
Was cristes bodi, in blod colour:
Þe Iewes wolden ha broken his bones.
And mony a prophete gan make mon,
And seide: lord! send us þi lomb
Out of þe wildernesses ston,
To fende vs from þe lyon cromp
Of mylde mount of Syon;
Be-com mon In a Maydens womb,
Made a bodi wiþ blessed bon,
In a Maidens blod þi bodi flomb;
At Barreres weore debate:
Þorwȝ stones In þe wildernes,
Men miȝte better ha crepet I-wis,
Þen bored in-to heuene blis,
Til blod brac vp þe ȝate.
Sin monnes sone was so nedi
To beo lad wiþ lomb[e] mylde,
Whi weore gylours so gredi
ffor to defoule my faire childe?
Cros! whi weore þou so redi
To rende my fruit feor in fylde?"
"Ladi, to make þe deuel dredi,
God schop me a scheld, schame to schilde,
Til lomb of loue dyede,
And on me ȝeld þe gost wiþ vois.
I was chose a Relik chois;
Þe signe of Ihesu cristes crois,
Þer dar no deuel abyde.
Moni folk I fende from heore fos,—
Cristes Cros þis sawes seide:—
Heuene ȝates weore closed clos,
Til þe lomb of loue dyede;
Þis is write in tixt and glos;
After Cristes deþ, prophetes preide
Til þe lomb of loue dyed and ros,
In helle pyne, monkynde was teyde.
At houre of his none,
Þe lomb of loue seyde his þouȝt:
Nou is folfuld, þat wel is wrouȝt;
A mon is out of bondes brouȝt,
And heuene dores vndone.
Wiþ þe ffader þat al schal folfille,
His sone to heuene is an help;
I was piler, and stod ful stille;
After oþur ȝiftes now gostes ȝelp.
Þe fend þat al þis world wolde kille,
His swerd he pulte vp in his kelp;
To helle he horlede from þat hille,
Beerynge as a Beore whelp.
A beore is bounden and beted,
Cristes Cros haþ craked his croun;
Þe lomb haþ leid þe Lyoun a-doun;
Þe lomb is lord in eueri toun,
So cristes blod haþ pleted.
In holy writ þis tale is herde,
Þat goode ȝiftes god vs ȝaf.
God seiþ himself he is schepherde;
And vche an heerde bi-houeþ a staf:
Þe Cros I calle þe heerdes ȝerde;
Þer-wiþ, þe deuel, a dunt he ȝaf,
And wiþ þe ȝerde, þe wolf he werde;
Wiþ duntes drof him al to draf.
Þe Cros þis tale tolde,
Þat he was staf in þe heerdes hond;
Whon schep breken out of heore bond,
Þe wolf he wered out of lond,
Þat deuoured cristes folde."
Ȝit seide þe Meke Marie:
"Roode! þou reendest my Rose al red,
Þreo Iewes coomen from Caluari
Þat day þat Ihesu þoled ded;
Alle þei seiden þei weore sori;
ffor-dolled in a dronknyng dred,
Þei tolden hem alle wherfore and whi
Heore hertes were colde as lumpyng led;
Þe furste heore tale tolde:
'Whon crist was knit with corde on a stok,
His bodi bledde aȝein þat blok;
Þorw feet and hondes nayles gan knok,
Þen gan myn herte to colde.'
Þe Secounde seide: 'nay, not þat!
Þat dude serwe in-to myn herte schete,
But whon þe Roode ros, & doun was squat,
Þe nayles renten him hondes and feete;
Þorw-out his helm, þe harde hat,
Þe þornes, in-to his flesch gan crepe;
His Ioyntes vn-Ioynet, I tok good gat;
Þo weop I water, and teeres leete,
To care I was enclyned;
In cloddres of blod, his her was clunge;
Þe flesch was from þe bones swonge;
Druiȝe drinkeles was his tonge;
His lippes to-clouen and chyned.'
Þe þridde seide: 'þis þouhte me lest[? MS. left]
Of þeose peynes and oþer mo,
Þis peyne þouhte me peyne mest,
Al his flesch he let of flo.
His Mylde Moder stod him nest,
Loked vpward, And hire was wo.
A swerd swapped hire þorw þe brest;
Out of þe cros þe knyf com þo;
Þis siht sauh I my-selue;
Þe swerd of loue þorw hire gan launce;
Heo swapte on swownyng þorw þat chaunce:
To scornen hire þei gan daunce,
Iewes bi ten and twelue.'
Sin Iewes made so muchel mon
To seon my brid bounden in brere;
In sad serwyng moste I gon,
To seon blodi my chyldes chere.
ffadres & Modres þat walken in won,
Schul loue heore children beo skiles clere;
Þeose two loues weore in me al on,
ffor fader and moder I was here;
Þeose two loues in me weore dalt;
I was fader of his flesch;
His Moder hedde an herte nesch;
Mi serwe flowed as water fresch;
Weopyng and wo I walt.
IN me weore tacched sorwes two:
[I]n þe fader mihte non abyde,
ffor he was euere in reste and Ro,
Ioyned in his Ioyes wyde.
I serwed sore for to sei so;
I say whon þat my derlyng dide;
Wiþ duntes he was to deþe i-do;
Vp-on a tre his bodi was soyled.
Whon trouþe is told and darted,
Of alle Ioyes God is welle,
Þer mihte no serwe in him dwelle,
I serwed sore, as Clerkes telle;
Mi pyne was not departed.
ÞE hattore loue, þe caldore care,
Whon frendes fynde heore fruit defoyled;
Þe dispitous Iewes nolde not spare
Til trie fruit weore tore and toyled.
Neuer Mayden Mournede mare;
I sauh my child ben surded and soyled,
Myn herte to-clef wiþ swerd of care;
I sauȝ my brid with blod bem[MS. ben]-oyled.
As Symeon seide beo-forn,
Þe swerde of serwe, scharp I-grounde,
Schulde ȝiue myn herte a wounde:
In more wo þen I was bounde,
Neuere buirde haþ born.
Þe dede worþily gan wake;
Þe dai turned to nihtes donne;
Þe Merke Mone gan Mournyng make;
Þe lyht out leop of þe sonne;
Þe temple walles gan chiuere & schake;
Veiles in þe temple, a-two þei sponne.
Cros! whi noldestou not crake,
Whon rihtful blod on þe was ronne,
And kuyndes losten heore kende?
Whon my fruit on þe was fast,
Cros! whi weore þou not agast?
Þow stod stif as eny mast,
Whon lyf left vp his ende.
Whon þat Prince of Paradys
Bledde boþe brest and bak,
An heþene clerk was seint Denys:
He seide, þis world wente al to wrak;
He sauȝ þe planetes passen out of here pris;
Þe brihte sonne gan waxen blak:
Þe clerk þat was so wonderly wys,
Wonder wordes þer he spak.
Denys, þis grete Clerke, seide,
'Þe day of doom draweþ to an ende;
Al vr kuyndes haþ lost vr kende,
Til God þat dyed for vch a kuynde,
ffor Monnes kuynde deyde.'
Foules fellen out of heore fliht;
Beestes gan Belwe in eueri binne.
Cros! whon Crist on þe was cliht,
Whi noldestou not of mournyng minne?"
Þe Cros seide, "ladi briht!
I bar ones þi fruit for monnes sinne,
More to amende monnes riht,
Þen for eny weolþe þat I gan winne;
Wiþ blod, God bouȝte his broþer.
Whon Adam, Godes biddyng brak,
He bot a bite þat made vs blak,
Til fruit weore tied on treo wiþ tak;
O fruit for anoþer.
Sin Cristes Cros þat kepeþ ȝifte,
Graunted of þe fadres graunt,
I was loked I schulde vp lifte
Godes sone and maydenes faunt,
No Mon hedde scheld of schrifte;
Þe deuel stod lyk a lyon raumpaunt,
Mony folk In-to helle he clihte,
Til þe crosses dunt ȝaf him a daunt.
Mi dedes are bounden and booked;
Alle þe werkes þat I haue wrouht,
Weore founden in þe ffaderes fore-þouht;
Þerfore, ladi, lakkeþ me nouht,
I dude as me was looked.
Þorw Blod & watur, cristendam was wrouht,
Holy writ witnesseþ hit wel,
And in wille of soþfast þouht
A Mon mai be cristened skil;
Þat blod þat us alle bouht,
Digne cristenyng gan vs del.
At cristenyng, crist for-ȝat vs nouht,
His blessede blod whon we gan fel.
Maiden, Moder, and Wyue,
Þi fruit haþ ȝiuen vs baptem:
Cristened we weore In Red[de] rem,
Whon his bodi bledde on þe Beem
Of Cipresse and Olyue.
As Ihesu seide to Nichodemus,
'But a Barn be twyȝes born,
Whon domus-day schal blowen his bemus,
He may elles liggen loddere for-lorn.
ffurst of a wombe þer reuþe remus;
Siþþe in a font þer synne awey is schorn.'
I was cros to monnes quemus,
I bar þe fruit þow bar bi-forn
ffor þi beryng Al one.
But ȝif I hedde I-boren him eft,
ffrom riche reste mon hedde beo-reft.
In a loren logge I-left,
Ay to grunte and grone.
Þou art I-Crouned heuene quene,
Þorw þe burþe þat þou beere;
Þi garlond is al of graces grene,
Helle, Emperesse, in heuene Empere;
I am a Relyk þat shineþ shene,
Men wold wite wher þat I were.
At þe parlement wol I bene,
On domes-day prestly a-pere,
Whon Ihesu schal seye riht þere,
'Trewely, vppon þe Roode tre,
Mon, I dyede for þe.
Mon, what hastou don for me
To beon my frendly feere?'
At þe parlement, shul putten vp pleynyng,
Hou Maydenes fruit on me gan sterue,
Spere & spounge and sharp nayling
Þorw þe harde hat þe heued shal kerue,
Shul preie to þat rihtful kyng;
Vche mon schal haue as þei a-serue;
Rihtful schul ryse to riche restyng,
Truyt and tripet to helle shal sterue.
Mayden, Meoke and Mylde,
God haþ taken in þe his fleschly trene;
I bar þi fruit leoþi and lene;
Hit is riht þe Roode helpe to a-rene
Wrecches þat wraþþe þi chylde."
ÞE queen a-cordet wiþ þe cros,
And aȝeyn him spak no more speche.
Þe queen ȝaf þe Cros a cos;
Þe ladi of loue, loue gan seche,
Þeiȝ hire fruit on him were diȝt to dros,
Whon rendyng ropus gan him reche.
Cristes cros haþ kept vs from los,
Maries preyers, And God, vr leche,
Þe qween and þe Cros acorde.
Þe qween bar furst, þe cros afturward,
To fecche folk from helleward,
On holy stayers to steyen vpward,
And regne wiþ God vr lorde.
ÞE Clerk þat fourmed þis figour,
Of Maries wo to wite som,
He saih him-self þat harde stour,
Whon godes armus weore rent aroun.
Þe Cros is a cold Creatour,
And euere ȝit haþ ben def and dom.
Þeiȝ þis tale beo florisshed with faire flour,
I preue hit on Apocrafum,
ffor witnesse was neuer foundet
Þat neuere cristes cros spak;
Oure ladi leide on him no lak;
Bot to pulte þe deuel abak,
We speke hou crist was woundet.
IN ffleschly wede, God ganMS. gam him hede, Of Mylde May,
Was bore to blede, As Cristes Crede Soþly wol say;
On a stokly stede He Rod, we Rede, In Red Array;
ffrom deueles drede, Þat Duyk vs lede, At domes-day,These 4 lines are written as 4 stanzas, aab, in the MS. See st. 1.
Whon peple schal parte and pace
To heuene halle, or to helle woode,
Cristes cros and cristes blode,
And Marie preiers þat ben ful goode,
Grant vs þe lyf of grace! Amen!
LG.TRAILER:
Explicit disputacio inter Mariam
Et Crucem, secundum Apocrafum.

DIV2.HEAD: LIII. Susannah, or Seemly Susan.
DIV2.P: [28 alliterative Stanzas of thirteen: abab abab, cdddc, the last adding a couplet aa.]

LG.L: Þer was in Babiloine a bern, in þat borw riche,
Þat was a Ieuȝ ientil, & Ioachin he hiht;
He was so lele in his lawe, þer liued non him liche;
Of alle riche arayes, þat renkeMS. þat renke arayes (Gollancz) he was riht;
His Innes & his orchardus were with a dep dich,
Halles & herbergages, heiȝ vppon heiht.
To seche þoru þat cite, þer nas non sich,
Of erbus, and of erberi, so auenauntliche I-diht
Þat day,
Wiþ-Inne þe sercle of sees
Of Erberi, and Alees,
Of alle Maner of trees
Soþely to say.
¶ He hed a wif hiȝt Susan, was sotil and sage;
Heo was Elches douȝtur, eldest and eyre,
Louelich & liliewhit, on of þat lynage,
Of alle fason of foode, frelich and feire;
Þei lerned hire lettrure of þat langage,
Þe Maundement of Moises þei marked to þat may,
To þe Mount of Synai þat went in Message
Þat þe Trinite bi-tok of tables a peire
To Rede.
Þus þei lerne hire þe lawe,
Cleer Clergye to knawe;
To God stod hire gret awe,
Þat wlonkest in weede.
¶ He hedde an orchard newe, þat neiȝed wel nere,
Þer Iewus with Ioachim priueliche gon playe,
For he real & riche, of rentes euer þere,
Honest and auenaunt, and honorablest aye,
I-wis þer haunted til her hous, hende, ȝe mai here,
Two demers[MS. do|mus] of þat lawe, þat dredde were þat day,
Preostes and presidens, preised als peere,
Of whom vr souerein lord sawes gan say,
And tolde
How heor wikkednes comes,
Of þe wrongwys domes
Þat þei haue gyue to gomes,
Þis Iuges of olde.
¶ Þus þis dredful demers on daies þider drewe,
Al for gentrise and Ioye of þat Iuwesse,
To go in his gardeyn, þat gayliche grewe:
To fonge flourus and fruit, þouȝt þei no fresse;
And whon þei seiȝ Susan, semelich of hewe,
Þei weor so set vppon hire, miȝt þei not sese,
Þei wolde enchaunte þat child, hou schold heo eschewe;
And þus þis cherlus vnchaste, in chaumbre hir chese Wiþ chere.
Wiþ two Maidenes al on,
Semelyche Suson,
On dayes in þe merion,
Of Murþes wol here.
¶ Whon þeos perlous prestes perceyued hire play,
Þo þouȝte þe wrecches to bewile þat worly in wone;
Heore wittes wel wai-wordus þei wrethen awai,
And turned fro his teching, þat teeld is in trone.
ffor siht of here souerayn, soþli to say,
Heore hor heuedus fro heuene þei hid apon one;
Þei cauȝt, for heor couetyse, þe cursyng of kai;
ffor riȝtwys Iugement recordet þei none,
Þey two.
Euery day bi day,
In þe Pomeri þei play,
Whiles þei mihte Susan assay,
To worchen hire wo.
¶ In þe seson of somere, with Sibelle and Ione,
Heo greiþed hire til hire gardin, þat growed so grene;
Þer lyndes and lorers were lent vpon lone,
Þe sauyne and sypres, selcouþ to sene,
Þe palme and þe poplere, þe pirie, þe plone,
Þe Iunipere ientel, Ionyng bi-twene,
Þe rose ragged on rys, richest on Rone,
I-þeuwed with þe þorn, trinaunt to sene,
So tiht.
Þer weore Pope-iayes prest,
Nightyngales vppon nest,
Bliþest Briddes o þe best,
In Blossoms so briht.
¶ Þe Briddes, in Blossoms, þei beeren wel loude,
On olyues and amylliers, and al kynde of trees:
Þe popeiayes perken, and pruynen for proude;
On peren and pynappel, þei ioyken in pees,
On croppus of canel, keneliche þei croude;
On grapes þe goldfinch þei gladen and glees.
Þus schene briddus in schawe schewen heore schroude;
On ffirres and fygers, þei fongen heore seetes
In ffay.
Þer weore growyng so grene,
Þe Date wiþ þe Damesene;
Turtils troned on trene,
By sixti, I sayȝ.
¶ Þe fyge and þe filbert were fodemed so fayre,
Þe chirie and þe chestein, þat chosen is of hewe,
Apples and Almaundus, þat honest are of ayre,
Grapus and garnettes, gayliche þei grewe.
Þe costardes comeliche in cuþþes þei cayre,
Þe Britouns, þe Blaunderers, Braunches þe bewe,
ffele flourus and fruit, frelich of flayre,
With wardons winlich, and walshenotes newe,
Þey waled.
Ouer heor hedes gon hyng
Þe wince and þe wederlyng;
Spyces speden to spryng,
In Erbers enhaled.
¶ Þe chyue and þe chollet, þe chibolle, þe cheue,
Þe chouwet, þe cheuerol, þat schaggen on niht;
Þe persel, þe passenep, poretes to preue,
Þe pyon, þe peere, wel proudliche I-piht;
Þe lilye, þe louache, launsyng wiþ leue,
Þe sauge, þe sorsecle, so semeliche to siht;
Columbyne and Charuwe, clottes þei creue,
With Ruwe and Rubarbe, Ragget ariht,
No lees;
Daysye and Ditoyne,
Ysope and Aueroyne,
Peletre and Plauntoyne,
Proudest In pres.
¶ Als þis schaply þing, ȝede in hire ȝarde
Þat was hir hosbondus, and hire þat holden with hende,
"Nou folk be faren from us, þar us not be ferde;
Aftur myn oynement warliche ȝe weende;
Aspieþ nou specialy þe ȝates ben sperde,
ffor we wol wassche us I-wis bi þis welle strende."
ffor-þi þe wif werp of hir wedes vn-werde;
Vndur a lorere ful lowe þat ladi gan leende
So sone.
By a wynliche welle,
Susan caste of hir kelle;
Bote feole ferlys hire bi-felle
Bi Midday or none.
¶ Nou were þis domus men derf drawen in derne,
Whiles þei seo þat ladi was laft al hire one;
fforte heilse þat hende, þei hiȝed ful ȝerne;
With wordus þei worshipe þat worliche in wone:
"Wolt þou, ladi, for loue, on vre lay lerne,
And vndur þis lorere ben vr lemmone?
Ȝe ne þarf wonde for no wiȝt vr willes to werne;
ffor alle gomus þat scholde greue, of gardin ar gone
In ffeere.
Ȝif þou þis neodes deny,
We schal telle trewely,
We toke þe wiþ a-voutri
Vnder þis Lorere."
¶ Þen Susan was serwful, and seide in hire þouȝt,
"I am with serwe bi-set on eueriche syde:
Ȝif I assent to þis sin, þat þis segges haue souȝt,
I be bretenet and brent in baret to byde;
And ȝif I nikke hem with nai, hit helpeþ me nouȝt:
Such toret and teone takeþ me þis tyde.
Are I þat worthliche wrethe,[MS. wreche] þat al þis world wrouȝt,
Betere is wemles weende of þis world wyde."
Wiþ þis,
Þo Cast heo a Careful cri,
Þis loueliche Ladi:
Hir seruauns hedde selli,
No wonder I-wis.
¶ Whon kene men of hir court comen til hir cri,
Heo hedde cast of hir calle, and hire keuercheue;
In at a priue posterne þei passen in hi,
And findes þis prestes wel prest, her poyntus to preue:
Þo seide þe loselle a-loude to þe ladi,
"Þou hast gon wiþ a gome, þi god to greue,
And ligge with þi lemon In a-voutri:
Bi þe lord and þe lawe þat we onne leeue,"
Þey swere.
Alle hire seruauns þei shont,
And stelen a-wey in a stont;
Of hire weore þei neuer wont
Such wordes to here.
¶ Hir kinrede, hir cosyns, and al þat hire knewe,
Wrong handes I-wis, and wepten wel sore,
Sykeden for susan, so semeliche of hewe;
Al onwyse of þat wyf, wondred þei wore.
Þei dede hire in a dungon, þer neuer day dewe,
While domus men were dempt, þis dede to clare,
Marred in Manicles þat made wer newe,
Meteles, whiles þe Morwen to Middai & mare,
In drede.
Þer com hir fader so fre,
Wiþ al his affinite;
Þe prestes sauns pite,
And ful of ffalshede.
¶ Þo seide þe Iustises on bench to Ioachim þe Iewe,
Þat was of Iacobus kynde, gentil of dedes;
"Let senden aftur Susan, so semelych of hewe,
Þat þou hast weddet to wif, wlankest in wedes.
Heo was in trouþe, as we trowe, tristi and trewe;
Hir herte holliche on him þat þe heuene hedes."
Þus þei brouȝt hire to þe barre, hir bales to brewe.
Nouþur dom ne deþ, þat day heo ne dredes
Als þare.
Hir hed was ȝolow as wyre,
Of gold fyned wiþ fyre;
Hire scholdres schaply and schire,
Þat bureliche was bare.
¶ Nou is Susan in sale, sengeliche arayed
In a selken schert, with scholdres wel schene.
Þo Ros vp with rancour þe Renkes reneyed;
Þis comelich accused with wordes wel kene:
Homliche on hir heued, heor hondus þei leyed,—
And heo wepte for wo, no wonder I wene,—
"We schul presenten þis pleint, hou þou euer be paied,
And sei sadliche þe soþ, riȝt as we haue sene,
O Sake."
Þus wiþ cauteles waynt,
Preostes presented þis playnt;
Ȝit schal trouþe hem a-taynt,
I dar vnder-take.
¶ "Þorw-out þe pomeri, we passed us to play,—
Of preiere and of penaunce was vre purpose;—
Heo com with two Maidens, al richeli þat day,
In riche robus arayed, red as þe rose.
Wylyliche heo wyled hir wenches a-way,
And comaunded hem kenely þe ȝates to close.
Heo eode to a ȝong mon in a valay,[alterd from valey]
Þe semblaunt of Susan wolde non suppose,
ffor soþ.
Be þis cause þat we say,
Heo wyled hir wenches a-way;
Þis word we witnesse for ay,
Wiþ tonge and wiþ toþ.
¶ Whon we þat semblaunt seiȝ, we siked wel sare,[alterd from sore]
ffor sert of hir souureyn, and for hir owne sake;
Vr copus weore cumberous, and cundelet vs care,
But ȝit we trinet a trot, þat traytur [to] take.
He was borlich and bigge, bold as a bare,
More miȝti mon þen we, his Maistris to Make.
To þe ȝate ȝaply þei ȝeoden wel ȝare,
And he lift vp þe lach, and leop ouer þe lake,
Þat ȝouthe.
Heo ne schunte for no schame,
But bouwed aftur for blame.
Heo nolde cuyþe vs his name,
ffor craft þat we couþe."
¶ Nou heo is dampned on deis, with deol þauȝ hir deu[e],
And hir domus men vnduwe do hir be with-drawen:
Loueliche heo louted, and lacched hir leue,
At kynred and cosyn þat heo hed euere i-knawen,[alterd from knowen]
Heo asked Merci with mouþ in þis mischeue:
"I am sakeles of syn," heo seide in hir sawen;
"Grete god of his grace, ȝor gultus for-ȝiue,
Þat doþ me derfliche be ded and don out of dawen
Wiþ dere.
Wolde god þat I miht
Speke wiþ Ioachim a niht,
And siþen to deþ me be diht,
I charge hit not a pere."
¶ Heo fel doun flat in þe flore, hir feere whon heo fond,
Carped to him kyndeli, as heo ful wel couþe:
"I-wis I wraþþed þe neuere, at my witand,
Neiþer in word ne in werk, in elde ne in ȝouþe,"
Heo keuered vp-on hir kneos, and cussed his hand,
"ffor I am dampned, I ne dar disparage þi mouþ."
Was neuer more serwful segge, bi se nor bi sande,
Ne neuer a soriore siht, bi norþ ne bi souþ,
Þo þare.
Þei toke þe ffeteres of hire feete,
And euere he cussed þat swete:
"In oþer world schul we mete:"
Seide he no mare.
¶ Þen Susan þe serwfol seide uppon hiȝt,
Heef hir hondus on hiȝ, bi-held heo to heuene:
"Þou maker of Middelert þat most art of miht,
Boþe þe sonne and þe see, þou sette vppon seuene;
Alle my werkes þou wost, þe wrong and þe riht,
Hit is nedful nou þi names to nempne
Seþþe I am deolfolich dampned, and to deþ diht.
Lord, herteliche tak hede, and herkne my steuene
So ffre!
Seþþe þou maiȝt not be sene
Wiþ no fleschliche eyene,
Þou wost wel þat I am clene;
Haue Merci nou on me!"
¶ Nou þei dresse hire to deþ with-outen eny drede,
And lede forþ þat ladi, louesum of lere.
Grete god, of his grace, of gultes[? gyftes, G.] vngnede,
Help with þe holi gost, and herde hir preyere.
He directed þis dom, and þis delful dede,
To Danyel þe prophete, of dedes so dere,
Such ȝiftes god him ȝaf in his ȝouþehede:
Ȝit failed hit a fourteniht ful of þe ȝere,
Nouht layne.
Þo criede þat freoly foode,
"Whi spille ȝe Innocens blode?"
And alle þe[i] stoteyd and stode,
Þis ferlys to frayne.
¶ "What signefyes, gode sone, þese sawus þat þou seis?"
Þus þese Maisterful men [with] mouþes can mele.
"Þei be fendus, al þe frape, I sei hit in feiþ;
And in folk of I[s]rael be foles wel fele.
Vmbiloke ȝou, lordes; such lawes ben leiþ;
Me þinkeþ ȝor dedes vnduwe, such domus to dele.
Aȝein to þe ȝild-halle ȝe[MS. þe] gomes vn-greiþ;
I schal, be proces apert, disproue þis a-pele
ffor nede.
Lat twinne hem in two,
For now wakneþ heor wo;
Þei schal graunte, ar þei go,
Al heore falshede."
¶ Þei diseuered hem sone, and sette hem sere;
And sodeynly askede, þei brouȝt in-to þe sale;
Bi-fore þis ȝonge prophete þis preost gon apere,
And he him apeched sone with chekes wel pale,
"Þou hast I-be presedent, þe peple to steere;
Þou dotest nou on þin olde tos in þe dismale.
Now schal þi conscience be knowen, þat euer was vnclere;
Þou hast in babiloygne on benche brewed muche bale,
Wel bolde.
Nou schal ȝor synnes be seene,
Of ffals domes bi-deene,
ffor þeose In Babiloyne han bene
Iugget of Olde.
¶ Þou seidest þou seȝe Susanne sinned in þi siht.
Tel nou me trewly, vnder what tre?"
"Mon, bi þe muche god, þat most is of miht,
Vndur a Cyne, soþli my-seluen I hir se."
"Nou þou lyest in þin hed, bi heuen vppon hiht!
An Angel with a naked swerd þe neiȝes wel nere;
He haþ brandist his brond brennynde so briȝt,
To Marke þi middel at a Mase in more þen in þre,
No lese.
Þou Brak godes Comaundement,
To sle such an Innocent
Wiþ eny fals Iuggement
Vn-duweliche on dese."
¶ Nou is þis domus-mon with-drawen with-outen eni drede,
And put in-to prison aȝeyn in-to place.
Þei brouȝten þe toþur forþ, whom þe barn bede,
To-fore þe folk and þe faunt freli of face:
"Cum forþ, þou corsed caytif, þou Canaan!" he sede;
"Bi-cause of þi couetise þou art in þis case.
Þou hast disceyuet þi-self with þin oune dede;
Of þi wit for a wyf, bi-wiled þou wase
In wede.
Þou sey nou, so mote þou þe,
Vnder what kynde of tre,
Semeli Susan þou se
Do þat derne dede?
¶ Þou gome of gret elde, þin hed is grei hored;
Tel hit me treweli, ar þou þi lyf tyne."
Þo þat roþli cherl ruydely rored,
And seide bi-fore þe prophet, "þei pleied bi a prine."
"Nou þou liest loude, so helpe me vr lord!
ffor fulþe of þi falshed þou schalt ha euel pine;
Þou and þi cursed cumpere, ȝe mou not a-corde.
Ȝe schul be drawen to þe deþ þis dai ar we dine
So Raþe.
An Angel is neih honde,
Takes þe domes of ȝor honde,
Wiþ a Brennynge bronde
To byte ȝou baþe."
¶ Þen þe folk of Israel felle vppon knes,
And lowed þat loueli lord þat hire þe lyf lent.
Alle þe gomus þat hire god wolde gladen and glees,
Þis prophete so pertli proues his entent.
Þei trompe bifore þis traiturs, and traylen hem on tres
Þorow-out þe Cite, bi comuyn assent.
Hose leeueþ on þat lord, þar him not lees,
Þat þus his seruaunt saued þat schold ha be schent
In Sete.
Þis ferlys bi-fel
In þe days of Danyel:
Þe pistel witnesseþ wel
Of þat profete.
Ihesu crist, wiþ mylde steuene,
Graunt us alle þe blisse of heuene! Amen!

DIV2.HEAD: LIV. Testamentum Christi.

DIV3.HEAD: MS. Vernon, Fol. 317 b.

LG.L: "Jhesu, kyng of heuene and helle,
Mon and wommon, I wol þe telle
What loue I haue I-don to þe;
Loke what þou hast don to me!
Of alle Joye þou weore out pult
With resoun and wiþ þin oune gult;
Pore þou weore I-dryuen a-way,
As a best þat goþ on-stray.
ffrom my kindome I com doun,
Te seche þe from toun to toun;
Min heritage, þat is so fre,
In þi mischef to ȝiue hit þe.
And whon þat ȝifte I ȝiuen þe scholde,
I dude as þe lawe wolde:
To a Mayden I meked me,
ffor no chalange schulde be;
wel dernely I kepte þe and me
Til I my tyme wolde se,
ffourti wokes and fourti dawes,
To folfulle þe olde lawes.
þe Mayden was trewe, mylde & fre,
Heo receyued me for þe.
þorw my monhede and my grace,
þus com sesyng furst on place.
And whon þe sesyng was do so,
fful gret envye hedde þenne þi fo;
þenne Belsebub and Sathanas
Hedde gret wonder whi hit was;
þei fondede me wiþ felony,
wiþ pride, couetyse and gloteny,
And wel þei wuste I was a mon;
But synne in me founde þei non.
Harde þei þreted me in her þouȝt,
þat ilke sesyng schulde be deore abouȝt;
þei sende heore sergeauns with maystrie,
with wo and serwe me to distruye,
And wel þei founde hem geyned nouȝt.
Anoþur help was in my þouȝt:
More siker þe to make
Aȝeyn þi foos, ful of wrake,
Heuene and eorþe in present
To make a chartre of feffement;
In such a maner þen moste hit be
þat I moste ȝiue my lyf for þe:
ffor þou art ded, and I am lyf,
And I moste dye to ȝiue þe lyf.
Mony a wei haue I go
In hongur and þurst, colde and wo,
þritti winter and more þen two,
Or my dede weore al I-do
Ne mihte I fynde no parchemyn
ffor to laste wiþ-outen fyn;
Bote, as good loue bad me do,
Min oune skin I tok þer-to.
To gete me frendes, I ȝaf good mede;
So doþ þe pore þat haþ gret nede:
On a þoresday a soper I made,
Boþe frend and fo to maken glade,
wiþ mete and drynk to soulus fode,
with holi word my flesch and blode:
And þis I made for Monkynde,
Mi loue-dedes to haue in mynde:
Or I fro þe bord a-ras,
Of my frend bi-trayed I was;
He fond me goande in þe way,
As þe Leoun goþ to his pray:

L.HI1: Susceperunt me sicut leo paratus ad predam.

LG.L: A curtul I hedde and cloþus mo,
And sone I hedde hem alle for-go:
So hedde I þis chartre writen,
þo was I naked, wel may ȝe witen;
þei casten lot as wolde bi-falle,
wheþer on schulde haue hem or parten alle.
ffrend and fo þat with me metten,
In my neode alle me for-letten;
And to a piler I was I-piht,
Togget and tauwed al þe niht,
And wasschen in myn owne blode,
And strayte I-streynet on þe Rode,
Streyned to druye on Rode-tre,
As parchemyn oweþ for to be.
Here now, and ȝe schul witen
Hou þis chartre was I-writen.
Vppon myn neb was mad þe ynke
wiþ þe Jewes spittyng on me to stynke.
þe penne þat þe lettre was wiþ writen,
weore scourges þat I was wiþ smiten.
How mony lettres þeron beon,
Red, and þou miht wite and seon:
ffif þousend foure hundred fyfti and ten
woundus on me, boþe blak and wen.
To schewen on alle my loue-dede,
Mi-self I wole þis chartre rede.
Ȝe Men þat gon bi þis weye,
A-bydeþ a luytel, I ow preye,
And redeþ alle on þis parchemyn,
ȝif eny serwe beo lyk to myn:

L.HI1: O nos omnes qui transitis per uiam,

LG.L: Stondeþ and hereþ þis chartre red,
whi I am woundet and al for-bled.
'Sciant presentes & futuri,
wite ȝe þat are and schal be-tyde,
þat Jhesu crist wiþ blodi syde,
þat was boren in Bedleem
And offred in to Jerusalem,
þe kynges sone of heuene aboue,
with mi ffadres wille and loue
Made a sesyng whon I was born,
To þe, Monkynde, þat was forlorn.
wiþ my cha[r]tre here present
I make nou a confirmament:
þat I haue graunted and ȝiuen
To þe, Monkynde, with me to liuen
In my Rewme of heuene-blis,
To haue and to holden wiþ-outen mis,
In a condicion, ȝif þou be kynde
And my loue-dedes haue in Mynde;
ffre to haue, and fre to holde,
wiþ al þe purtynaunce to wolde,
Myn heritage þat is so fre.
ffor homage ne for feute
No more wol I aske of þe,
But a foure-leued gras ȝeld þou me:
Olef is soþfast schrifte,
þe toþur is for synne herte-smerte,
þe þridde is "I wol no more do so,"
þe feorþe is "drede god euermo";
whon þeose four leues to-geder ben set,
A "trewe loue" men clepen hit.
Of þis Rente boo nouȝt be-hynde,
ffor þorw þe ȝer þou may hit fynde;
Elles mai þou not fynde hit in my wounde,
ffor þer mai "trewe loue" wel be founde.
And ȝif þou falle and gretly mis-take,
Mi dede I wole neuer forsake;
And ȝif þou amende þe, and Merci craue,
þin heritage ȝut schalt þou haue.'
Þe seles þat hit was seled wiþ,
þei were grauen vp-on a stiþ;
Of gold nor seluer weore þei nouȝt,
Of stel and Iren were þei wrouȝt:
with þe spere of stel myn herte þei stongen
þorw myn herte and þorw my longen;
Iren nayles þurleden me
þorw feet and hondes to þe tre.
Þe selyng-wax was deore abouȝt,
At myn herte rote hit was souȝt,
And tempred al wiþ vermiloun
Of my rede blod þat ran doun:

L.HI1: Factum est cor meum tanquam cera liquescens in medio ventris mei.

LG.L: ffyue seles weore I-set þeron:
ffader and sone, god and mon;
þe fyfþe is for to leeue most,
þat icomen of þe holygost.
In pleyn pouwer þi stat to make,
A croune on myn hed [I gon] to take
Of þornus, in toknyng þat I am kyng
And freoly may ȝiue þe þi þing:
þis witnesseþ þis Jewes alle;
On kneos þei gonne to me falle,
And seiden loude on heore scornyng,
"Heil be þou, lord, and Jewes kyng!"
Bi-twene two men þis [chartre] was seeled;
þei boþe weore seke; þat on I heled,
Bi-twene two þeues on hih I-piht,
In toknyng þat I am mon of miht,
þat Norþ and West on heiȝ hille
þat I may deme boþe gode and ille,

L.HI1: Quia neque ab oriente neque ab occidente.

LG.L: A-þhurst I was ful sore I-swonken,
þe beuerege moste nede be dronken:
A loue-drynke I asked of þe;
Eysel and galle þou ȝaf to me:
þis witnesseþ Matheu and Jon,
Luk and Mark and monyon,
And nomeliche my moder swete;
ffor heo lafte neuere teres to lete:
Ar þis chartre writen was,
fful ofte heo seide allas allas!
So bare I was of worldes gode,
whon I schulde dye on þe Rode,
þat I hedde nouȝt wher-of to take,
Mi testament wher-of to make,
But of my leoue moder dere:
heo stod bi me with serwful chere;
And whon I my cosyn hire bi-toke,
heo caste me mony a serwful loke.
In knowleching I made a cri,
"Pater, pater, lamaȝabatani."
Bi-hold þou, mon, with herte and eȝe,
ffor þi loue hou I schal dye:
Consummatum est, þis chartre is doon.
Mon, þou hast ouercome þi foon!
To helle I wente, þis chartre to schewe
Bi-fore þi fo, Sathanas þe schrewe;
þo he was schent and brouht to grounde,
wiþ nayles bored and speres wounde,
A strayt couenaunt I-mad þer was
Bi-twene me and Sathanas:
Al my catel to haue away,
þat he me refte with false pray.
A ȝein I com, and made a feste
AMong þe leste and þe meste:
A parti þo gunne knowe me,
þat I was mon of gret pouste.
þe feeste laste fourti dawes,
To do men knowe my newe lawes;
þat feeste was al of ioye and blis,
þat Esterday ȝit cleped is.
On endenture I lafte wiþ þe,
þat euer þou schuldest siker be:
In preostes hondes my flesch and blode,
þat for þe dyede on þe Rode.
A by-keye I tok þe also:
þe token þat I was on I-do,
To bere with þe wher þat þou go;
þenne þar þe not drede of þi fo.
To my fader I moste gon,
ffor al his wille haue I don.
A cote-armour I bar with me,
ffor þat I tok of þy liuere;
þe cloþ was riche and ful fyn,
þe chaumpe hit was of red camelyn.
A ful feir mayden to me hit wrouȝt;
Oute of hire boure I hit brouȝt;
Poudret with fyue roses rede,
ffyf woundes þat I þoled dede.
whon I come eft aȝeyn to þe,
þer-bi þou maiȝt knowe me.
Þeose þat beoþ of rente be-hynde,
And þeose dedes haue not in mynde,
fful sore may þei ben a-dred
whon þis cha[r]tre schal be red:
Alle þeose schul go to helle-pyne;
And with me to blisse schul go alle myne.
Pay þi rente, keep þe from gylt,
Cum and cleyme whon þat þou wilt,
þe blisse þat loste oure frende."
to þe whuche blisce, crist vs bringe withouten ende!
