DIV3.HEAD: 1. Christ on the Cross.
DIV3.P: (6 stanzas of 10 lines each, abab ccb ccb. þ is for MS. y.)

LG.L: Hi sike al wan hi singe,
for sorue þat hi se:
Wan hic wit wepinge
bi-holde a-pon þe tre,
Hi se ihesu mi suete
his herte blode for-lete
for þe luue of me.
His wondis wexin wete:
Marie milde and sute,
þu haf merci of me!
Hey a-pon a dune,
as al folke hit se may,
a mile wytt-hute þe tune,
a-bute þe mid day,
þe rode was op a-reride:
his frendis werin al of-ferde,
þei clungin so þe cley.
þe rod stonit in ston,
Mari hir selfe al-hon,
hir songe was way-la-way.
Wan hic him bi-holde
wyt hey and herte boþe,
Hi se his bodi colde,
his ble waxit alle bloe;
He honge al of blode,
se hey a-pon þe rode,
bi-twixin þefis two.
Hu soldi singe mor?
Mari, þw wepe sor;
þu wist of al his woe.
Wel ofte wan hi siche,
hi make mi mone;
Hiuel hic[? hit] may me like,
and wondir nis hit non,
Wan hi se honge hey,
Ande bitter peynis drei,
Ihesu my lemmon.
His wondis sor[e] smerte,
þe sper his at his herte,
Ande þorit his side gon.MS. rubd
Þe naylis beit al to longe,
þe smyt his al to sleye,
þue bledis al to longe,
þe tre his al to heye,
þe stonis waxin wete:
Allas, ihesu, mi suete,
feu frendis hafdis þue;MS. rubd
But sin Ion murnid,
And Mari wepnid,
þat al þi sorug seys.
Wel ofte wan hi slepe,
wit soru hic ham þoit soit;
Wan hi wake and wende,
hi þenke in mi þoit,
Allas þat man beit wode!
bi-holdit an þe rode,
and silit hic [han broit]MS. rubd.
Hir souelis in to sin,
for any worlde hit? worldis. win,
þat was so der hi-boyt.

DIV3.HEAD: 2. Hail, Mary! Digby MS. 2, leaf 6, back.
DIV3.P: (A ryme-beginning poem.See Early English Poems and Lives of Saints, in Philol. Soc. Trans. 1872, and note the frequent central rymes here. 5 stanzas of 8 lines, aaaa abab.)

LG.L: Hayl, mari! hic am sori:
haf pite of me, and merci!
mi leuedi, to þe i cri:
for mi sinnis, dred ham hi,
wen hi þenke hat hi sal bi,
þat hi haf mis hi-don
in worde, in worke, in þoith, foli:
leuedi, her mi bon!
Mi bon þu her, leuedi der,
þat hic aske wit reuful cher!
þu len me her,'lefdi der' follows, dotted under as a mistake. wil hic am fer,
do penanx in mi praier;
ne let me noth ler, þat þu ber,
at mi nendin day;
þe worlais, þai wil be her,
fort[to] take þair pray.
To take þar pray, alse hi her say
þai er redi, boyt niteNote the absence of the guttural gh. Compare Capgrave's Chronicle, and his St. Katharine, E. E. T. Soc. and day;
so strange er þai, þat we ne may
A-gaynis þaim stond, so way la way,
but þu gif helpus, mittefulNote the absence of the guttural gh. Compare Capgrave's Chronicle, and his St. Katharine, E. E. T. Soc. may,
Wit þi sunes grace;
Wan þu comes, þai flet a-wai;
dar þai not se þi face.
Þi face to se, þu grant hit me,
lefdi ful-fillid of pite,
þat hi may be in Ioy wit þe,
to se þi sone in trinite,
þat sufferid pine, and ded for me
and for al man-kyn:
his flesse was sprade on rode tre,
to leysus al of sine.
Of sine and kar, he maked vs bar,
Wan he þollid pines sar;
to drupe and dar, we athe wel mare,
alse for þe hondis doyt þe har,
wan we þenke hu we sal far
wan he sal dem vs alle,
we sal haf ned[e þan &] þare,
a-pon mari to calle, &c.

DIV3.HEAD: 3. A Resolve to Reform.
DIV3.P: (A ryme-beginning poem. 3 stanzas of 6, aaab ab. þ is for MS. y.)

LG.L: No more willi wiked be;
Forsake ich wille þis world-is fe,
þis wildis wodis, þis folen gle;
ich wul be mild of chere:
of cnottis scal mi girdil be,
becomme[n] ich wil frere.
Frer menur i wil me make,
and lecherie i wille asake;
to ihesu crist ich wil me take,
and serue in holi churche,
all in mi ouris for to wake,
goddis wille to wurche.
Wurche i wille þis workes gode,
for him þat boyht us in þe rode;
from his side ran þe blode;
so dere he gan vs bie:
for sothe i tel him mor þan wode,
þat haytit? for 'hantith,' practises. licherieMS. Digby 86, c. 1275 A.D., leaf 125, back. Bodleian Library.

DIV3.HEAD: 4. Les diȝ de seint bernard comenceent .I. ci tres beaus.(Printed before in Anglia, III. 59, etc., by Varnhagen.)

LG.L: Þe blessing of heuene king,
And of his moder, þat swete þing,
Mote we all hauen!
He ous ȝeue good beginning,
And clene lif at oure ending;
Þat auhte we alle craven.
Lestneþ me a luitel þrowe,
Ȝe þat wilen ou selven cnowe!
Ounwis þau ich be,
.I. shal hou tellen, alse ich can,
Wat holy writ spekeþ of man;
Lestneþ nou to me!
Seint bernard seiþ in his bok,
Þa[t] man is werm, and wermes hok,
And wermes he shal feden;
Wen his lif him is bireued,
In his rug and in his heued
Shulen grisliche wermes breden.
Þe fles sal melten from þe bon,
Þe senewes sundren euerichon,
Þe body hit sal defien.
Ȝe þat wilen þat soþe .I.-seen,
Oundoþ þe graues þere þey been,
And lokeþ wat þere lien.
Mon, þou art a feble fom,
Ne hauest þou here non siker hom;
Ne seye ich þe bote skil;
Þi riȝte stude is helles wer;
Ihesus lete ous comen þer,
Þorou his swete wil!
Þi fles stont aȝein þi gost:
Wen þou shalt deyen, þou ne wost,
Nouþer day ne niȝt.
Nedes costes þou most deyen,
Ne may no rauncoun þe forbeyen;
Greyþe þe wiles þou miȝt!
A fikel wind, mon, is þi lif,
And deþ draweþ his sarpe knif;
Þou do þe sone sriue!
If þou counne loke riȝt,
Ne hauest þou here bote fiȝt,
Þe wiles þou art aliue.
For nou þou art wrong, nou þou art riȝt,
Nou þou art heui, nou þou art liȝt,
Þou skippest alse a ro;
Nou þou art sek, and nou þou coverest;
Nou þou art riche, and nou þou pouerest;
Ne is þis muchel wo?
Þi fles þe seyþ niȝt and day,
.I. wile hauen eise wil .I. may;
Þi soule þe seiþ nay:
If ich þe bere to muchel meþ,
Þou wilt me bringen helle deþ,
And wo þat lasteþ ay.
Þus hit goþ bitwenen hem two;
Þat on seiþ 'let,' þat oþer 'do,'
Ne cunneþ hey ne nere bilinnen;
Wel we mowen alle .I.-seen,
Þe soule auhte maister to been,
Þe pris hoe hautte to winnen.
Mon, be þou nout þi self ouncouþ;
Loke wat comeþ out at þi mouþ,
Ne findest þou non so fouvel dinghep,altered from 'dinhhep': l. 64 is written after l. 66.
Þey þou loke al abouten,
And elles wer wiþ-houten,
Wel hinderliche þou nim þe kep.
Þou hauest, man, in þat foule hous,
A þing þat is wel precious;
Wel dere hit wes .I.-bouht:
Ich helde þe for wilde and wod,
If þou letest so muchel god,
Þe deuel hauen for nouht.
Mon, be waker and be wis;
If þou doun fallest, sone aris,
Ne li þou none stounde:
Wiþ alle þi miȝte, if þou dost þis,
Þi soule seyt, and soþ hit is,
Ioye þou hauest .I.-founde.

LG.HEAD: (14: Man's Three Foes. The First, his Flesh.)
LG.L: Mon, þou hauest þre wikke fon;
Here nomes con ich euerich on;
Nou ich shal tellen alle:
Þin owene fles, þe world, þe fend;
He þat scholde ben þi frend,
He doþ þe raþest falle.
Þou cloþest him wiþ faire sroud,
Þou makest þi fomen fat and proud.
If ich hit dourste seyen;
Þou dost þi self wel muchel wrong,
Þou makest þi foman fat and strong
To fiȝten þe aȝein.
Þou do bi counsail and bi red;
Wiþdrau him hofte of his bred,
And luitel ȝef him to drinken;
Ne let him noþing Idel gon;
Þou do him pines mani on,
And ofte do him to swinken.

LG.HEAD: (17: Man's Second Foe, the World.)
LG.L: To coveitise of mani þing,
Þe werld þe draweþ; and misliking
Hit giueþ þe more and more.
Fals he his, and feir he semeþ,
And alrebest, wen he þe quemeþ,
He bindeþ þe wel sore.
Þou wost þe world shal gon to nout,
Ne hauest þou noþing hider ibrout,
Ne nout shalt bere wiþ þe;
Þou shalt alone gon þi way,
Wiþ-oute stede and palefray,
Wiþ-oute gold and fe.

LG.HEAD: (19: Man's Third Foe, the Fiend.)
LG.L: Þi þridde fo, þat foule wiȝt,
Þe fondeþ boþe day and niȝt,
Þeron hise gilles alle:
Þou wost wel he ne loueþ þe nout,
He fondeþ to chaunge þi þout,
And do þe for to falle.
Þou wost he ne wille þe no god;
He wolde hauen þin herte blod;
Þou be war of his hok!
Do nou also ich haue þe seid,
And alle þre sulen ben aleid
Wiþ here owene crok.
If þou seyst þis spelis hard,
Ne may .I. nout swech foreward
Holden, ne wel drie;
A litel þing ich axe þe;
Þou sei me soþ, par charite,
Þer-of þat þou ne lie.c. 1275. MS. Digby 86, leaf 126, back, col. 1.

DIV3.HEAD: 5. Ubi sonnt qui ante nos fuerount?

LG.L: Uuere beþ þey biforen vs weren,
Houndes ladden and hauekes beren,
And hadden feld and wode?
Þe riche leuedies in hoere bour,
Þat wereden gold in hoere tressour,
Wiþ hoere briȝtte rode,
Eten and drounken, and maden hem glad;
Hoere lif was al wiþ gamen .I.-lad,
Men keneleden hem biforen;
Þey beren hem wel swiþe heye;
And in a twincling of an eye
Hoere soules weren forloren.
Were is þat lawing and that song,
Þat trayling and that proude ȝong,
Þo hauekes and þo houndes?
Al þat ioye is went away,
Þat wele is comen to weylaway,
To manie harde stoundes.
Hoere paradis by nomen here,
And nou þey lien in helle .I.-fere;
Þe fuir hit brennes heuere:
Long is ay, and long is ho,
Long is wy, and long is wo;
Þennes ne comeþ þey neuere.
Dreȝy here man, þenne, if þou wilt,
A luitel pine þat me þe bit;
Wiþdrau þine eyses ofte;
Þey þi pine be oun-rede,
And þou þenke on þi mede,
Hit sal þe þinken softe.
If þat fend, þat foule þing,
Þorou wikke roun, þorou fals egging,
Þere ne þere þe haueþ .I.-cast,
Oup, and be god chaunpioun!
Stond, ne fal namore adoun
For a luytel blast!
Þou take þe rode to þi staf,
And þenk on him þat þereoune ȝaf
His lif þat wes so lef:
He hit ȝaf for þe; þou ȝelde hit him;
Aȝein his fo, þat staf þou nim,
And wrek him of þat þef!
Of riȝtte bileue þou nim þat sheld,
Þe wiles þat þou best in þat feld,
Þin hond to strenkþen fonde,
And kep þy fo wiþ staues ord,
And do þat traytre scien þat word;
Biget þat mvrie[? MS.] londe.
Þere-inne is day wiþ-houten niȝt,
Wiþ-outen ende, strenkþe and miȝt,
And wreche of euerich fo;
Mid god him-selwen eche lif,
And pes and rest wiþoute strif,
Wele wiþ-outen wo.
Mayden moder, heuene quene,
Þou miȝt and const, and owest to bene
Oure sheld aȝein þe fende:
Help ous sunne for to flen,
Þat we moten þi sone .I.-seen,
In ioye wiþ-outen hende. Amen!

DIV3.HEAD: 6. Channcoun de noustre Dame. (A Dialog between Christ on the Cross and his Mother.)Printed before in Anglia, II. 253 seq.

LG.L: "Stond wel, moder, ounder rode,
Bihold þi child with glade mode;
Moder, bliþe miȝt þou be,"
"Sone, how may ich bliþe stonde?
Ich se þine fet, and þine honde,
.I.-nayled to þe harde tre."
"Moder, do wey þi wepinge!
Ich þolie deþ for monnes kuinde;
Wor mine gultes ne þolie .I. non."
"Sone, ich fele þe deþes stounde;
Þat swerd is at min hertes grounde,
Þat me byheyte simeon."
"Moder, do wei þine teres:
Þou wip awey þe blodi teres;
Hy doþ me worse þene mi deþ."
"Sone, hou miȝtte ich teres werne?
I se þine blodi woundes herne
From þin herte to þi fot."
"Moder, nou .I. may þe seye,
Betere is, þat ich one deye,
Þen alle mankyn to helle go."
"Sone, .I. se þi body .I.-swonge,
Þin honde, þin fet, þi bodi .I.-stounge:
Hit nis no wonder þey me be wo."
"Moder, if ich þe dourste telle,
If ich ne deye, þou gost to helle:
.I. þolie deþ for monnes sake."
"Sone, þou me bi-hest so milde;
.I.-comen hit is of monnes kuinde,
Þat ich sike, and serewe make."
"Moder, merci, let me deye,
And Adam out of helle beye,
And monkin þat is forlore."
"Sone, wat sal me þe stounde?
Þine pinen me bringeþ to þe grounde;
Let me dey[e] þe bifore!"
"Swete moder, nou þou fondest
Of mi pine þer þou stondest;
Wiþ-houte mi pine nere no mon."
"Sone, .I. wot .I. may þe telle,
Hote hit be, þe pine of helle;
Of more pine, ne wot .I. non."
"Moder of moder, þus .I. fare;
Nou þou wost wimmanes kare;
Þou art clene mayden on."
"Sone, þou helpest alle nede,
Alle þo þat to þe wille grede,
May and wif, and fowel wimmon."
"Moder, .I. ne may no lengore dwelle,
Þe time is comen, .I. go to helle:
I þolie þis for þine sake."
"Sone, .I.-wis .I. wille founde?
.I. deye almest; .I. falle to grounde:
So serwful deþ nes never non!"

DIV3.HEAD: 7. Here biginneþ þe same of Seint bede, prest.
DIV3.P: (7 stanzas of 6, aab, aab, or aab, ccb.)

LG.HEAD: (1; Of Heaven and Hell.)
LG.L: Holi gost, þi miȝtte
Ous wisse and rede and diȝte,
And help ous and teche
To witen ous wiþ þe onwiȝtte,
Þat bi day and by niȝtte
Þencheþ ous bipeche,
Makeþ ous to don sunne,
And abben to monkunne
Swiþe muchel honde.
He þencheþ ous biwinne,
And wonien ous wiþinne,
And ouer ous habben honde:
Ac bidde we crist ȝerne
Hou þat he hem werne
For his mildenesse,
For hy þat to hem sulen turne,
In helle hy shulen forberne,
In hewche þesternesse.
We houten oure suppinde
Herien of alle þinge,
And louien hine wel swiþe,
For he ous wille werien,
Þat fendes ous ne derien,
Þat folle beþ of niþe;
Ne be we nout here
Swiþe fele ȝere,
Bote we her, we henne wende:
Makein ous clene and skere,
Þat we in heuene, englene fere,
Ben ho wiþ-outen ende.
In heuene, in þe blisse
Þat muchel is midiwisse,
And lesteþ euere more;
Þer-inne is reste and lisse;
Ne may þer no mon misse,
Þat louieþ godes ore.
Ac hit saiþ in þe gospelle,
Ne may non tounge al telle,
Þe blisse þat þer is euere,
Ne þe pine of helle,
Þer-to we beþ wel swelle,
Awey hit ne hendeþ nevere.
Þer-inne is chele and hete,
And hounger ounimete,
And þurst alles to kene;
Pikede beþ þe shete,
And wormes þer beþ kete,
To don þe soule tene.
Þerinne is wop and woninge,
And muchel bimeninge
Þat hoe .I.-boren were;
Ac þer nis non hendinge,
Ne non aȝein-cher-hinge,
Þat enes comeþ þere.
Wel we owen nimen gome
He þat elles þider come,
And seruen heuene kinge,
And bidden him .I.-lome,
Þat he ous at þe dome,
Of here pine bringe.
Oute we owre sunnen leten,
And munien crist, and beten,
Of alle oure misdede;
To doinde hoe beþ swete,
For-þy ous is helle ȝete,
Helle þat is ounlede.

LG.HEAD: (12: aab, aab. The Seven Chief Sius.)
LG.L: Þe seuene heued sunne
Þat we beþ ofte wiþinne,
Þe soule wolleþ amerre;
Hoe beþ of swikele kunne,
Þermide þe wiþerwinne
Ous alle þencheþ to bicherre.

LG.HEAD: (13: aaa, bba)
LG.L: Modinesse, and ouerfastnesse,
Onde, wrathes, swikelnesse,
Hordom, and ȝeuernesse;
Þis we houten alle ounderstonde,
Þat moni men in londe
Bringeþ to sorinesse.

LG.HEAD: (14: aab, aab)
LG.L: For þis beþ þe seuene
Þat bringeþ out of heuene,
Swiþe fele monne;
Þe weyes beþ in hoere wene
Mid wepinde steuene;
In-to helle hoe shulen þenne.

LG.HEAD: (15: aab, ccb. The Pride of Rich Folk.)
LG.L: Hoe weneþ monie of þise riche,
Þat he henglen ben .I.-liche
For hoere proude cloþe,
And þerfore hoe sulen scriken,
And in helle siken,
And crien hit foul wrothe.

LG.HEAD: (16: aab, aab)
LG.L: So weneþ þis wreche,
Þat hoe ne weren riche
For-þi þat hoe haytte nabbeþ;
Ac? MS. 'et': also in other lines. satanas þe wreche
Þe soule wille drecche
Wen hoe ani got habbeþ.
Þer iche midiwisse
Miȝtte comen to blisse,
If he hit wolde her nye,
And þe wreche may wel misse,
Bote he his pouernesse
In mildenesse þolie.

LG.HEAD: (18: The Sins of Monks and Priests.)
LG.L: Þis monekes weneþ soumme,
Þat gedereþ garisoumme,
Þat hoe hit shulen brouke;
Ac wene? MS. At-wene. þe deþ shal comen,
Hit shal hem ben binomen,
Bitaut hoe beþ þe pouke.
Þe prest þat singeþ masse
Þoru godes herienesse,
And wot of techinge,
And þer-of nul don almesse,
In euche sorinesse
His soule he may bringe.

LG.HEAD: (20: The Sins of Knights.)
LG.L: Þes kniȝttes beþ wel bolde,
For hy abbeþ aquolde
Here ani cristine were;
For-þi sa[t]anas þe holde
Þe soule wil atholde,
And makien hire oun i-fere.

LG.HEAD: (21: The Sins of Lawyers.)
LG.L: Þes plaidours beþ wel kene,
Þat werieþ red and grene.
And al þis ounriȝt demeþ:
Hy shulen, wiþ-houten wene,
To helle þat is so kene,
Þer þe fendes remeþ.

LG.HEAD: (22: The Sins of Chapmen.)
LG.L: Þis chapmen monie bi strete,
Hy beþ swikele ounimete,
Hy ne reccheþ þan hy swerien
For to abben here biȝete;
For-þi satanas þe kete,
Here soule wille derien.

LG.HEAD: (23: The Working Bondman.)
LG.L: Of alle men on londe,
Mest swinkeþ þe bonde,
And mest biȝet mit riȝte;
If he couþe ounderstonde
And teþege riȝt ounder his honde,
To crist he comen miȝtte.
Ac for alle his biswinke,
If he may comen to sottes drinke,
And stelen cristes teuþinge,
Sstrong deþ hit wile him þenke,
Depe in helle winke
His soule he may bringe.

LG.HEAD: (25: The Sins of Proud Ladies.)
LG.L: Þes proude leuedies
Þat louen driweries,
And breken here spousinge,
And doþ to-gabbie,
Þat loveden simonie
Of eni gode þinge;
Hy draweþ here wede,
Mid selkene þrede
.I.-frendet and .I.-bounde:
Swart and swiþe ounlede
Bemen hy shulen, and grede
Depe in helle grounde.

LG.HEAD: (27: Lecherous Monks and Nuns.)
LG.L: Monekes and eremites and nonnen,
Þat hem witen ne cunnen
Wiþ swecche lecherie,
Hy shulen to þere oun-winne:
Alle here cloþes dounne
Ne shulen hem warauntie.
Soþliche al betere him were
Þat hy .I.-boren nere,
Þat þider shule wende:
Warin ich ou here;
For ȝe þat enes comeþ þere,
Þer ȝe beþ ha-bouten hende.
AatMS. Aat for Ac hy weneþ libbie
And longe sunegie,
And þene at þen ende
Here sunnen al anendie,
And birewsie,
And seþþen to heuene wende.
Ne ben ȝe nout so ownriste
Nou to ihesu criste,
Þer-to ich ou lere;
For þer nes non þat weste,
Wiþ-houten ihesu criste,
Wen his hon day were.
For ous ne beþ nout so eþe
To-ȝeines houre deþe,
Þawe ous moowen so wel hede,
Ne speken bote ounþewe,
For ous beþ stronge and wreþe
To beten oure misdede.
Nout wiþ criste scolde
Beten ous þenne on londe
To habben houre riȝtte,
Wen we him seruen nolde,
Ne laufoul ben, ne holde,
Her we non forþer ne miȝtte.
Soþliche, wen we beþ dede,
Euerich sal fongen mede
After his herihinge,
Bote we ous þe bet bihede,
Þe soule hit shal .I.-frede,
Þat fareþ to pininge.
Þe hali me bindeþ,
In here me him þringeþ,
And bringeþ him hounder erþe,
Wor meshim .I.-findeþ,
To axnen hoe him grindeþ,
Þarto hy shulen worþe.
He liþ and roteþ lowe,
He ne haueþ þat be his owe
Of aytte ne of londe,
Ne nowþer mey ne mowe,
Þat þer doren a þrowe
Bi hem sitten ne stonde.
AcMS. At wer beþ þanne his haytte,
Þa he here raytte,
And in þis lif wonne?
Soþliche hy beþ bi-payȝtte,
Swecche oþere hoe beþ bitaiȝtte,
Lat him no þonk ne cunne.
Ac wer beþ þenne his ringes,
And his proude þinges,
And his golt-peinte gloue?
Wor al his proude þinges,
Ne vailleþ him no þinges
Þenne to his bihoue.
Sothliche, naked and bare,
Wiþ wop and wiþ kare,
Þou come to þisse liue;
And so ȝe sulen eft-senes fare;
.I. saye þe soth wiþ-oute sware;
Greyþeþ ou biliue!

LG.HEAD: (39: nine lines)
LG.L: Þe salt þe world forleten and lewe,[? rvmes]
Þer-of ȝe shulden þenken ene,
And oure sunne aquenche
Mid beden and mid almesse,
Wiþ-outen idelnesse,
If ȝe miȝtten at-blenche
From þe sori satanasse,
And from his swikelnesse
And from his heuele wrenche.
If þou fallest in sunne,
Ne li þou nout þer-inne;
Hieþe þe oup to arisen,
And shend þe wiþerwine
Satanas mid his pine,
And doþe also þe wise.
For mon nohute nout to abbe soule,
Wen his wrecche licome
In sunnen be .I.-falle,
Ac abbeyes houte dome,
And ounwren his sunnen .I.-lome,
And crist in fuir pineþ alle.

LG.HEAD: (42: The Good of Shrift.)
LG.L: Þe mon him let wel sriven,
And þene fend out driven,
Ne þarf him nout shomie,
For ne beþ in þisse live,
Wepmen ne wimmen fiue
Þat ofte ne svnegieþ.
At? for Ac þes modie gome
And leuedies and þe ounrome
Louteþ hem also þe ounwise,
And þes ȝounlinges somme,
Þey þat hoe to srifte come,
Hoe beþ sottes and shomefaste.
Hy nulleþ soþ tellen,
Þan me shulde hem quellen,
Hy ounsweren here misdede:
For-þi hoe shulen in helle
Euere gronen and swelle,
And euere-mo ben þer-inne.
Wenne eni gromeþ sore,
Þe grome þuncheþ more
Þen al hore oþer pine.
To þe bi prestes lore
Nolden herien godes hore,
Þenne hoe hit shullen biwine.

LG.HEAD: (46: The Last Judgment.)
LG.L: At þe mounte of olifete,
Þer we ous shulen alle .I.-mete;
Þe gode and þe ounwreste,
Þe day worþ milde and sete;
And bitter unimete
To hem þat forlete
To don godes heste.
Þer cumeþ god on his rode,
And his side his a blode,
And seweþ on he ous boute.
Afered beþ þenne þe gode,
And wo is þenne þe ouermode
Þat þer-of ne route.
"Lokeþ," seyþ god nouþe,
"Wat ich for ou ouþe,
Wat ich for ou gon þolie;
Luitel þonk ȝe me couþe,
Ne mid werke ne mid mouþe
Nolden ȝe me þonkie."
AtFor Ac he seyþ þenne to þe gode,
And to his milde moder,
"Ȝe duden gode dede;
Ȝe me fedden and srudden,
And wel me bihedden
Þo ich among ou hede,
And leide me a softe bedde;
Þarfore ich ou wole aredde,
For nou ȝe habbeþ nede."
Þe gode segeþ þenne,
"Louerd, were and wenne
Duden we þe gode deden?"
"Ȝuse," he seiþ, "þe poure monne,
Þo hoe help neden nen,
Bote as hoe for me beden;
"AtFor Ac ȝe, mine gode midiwisse,
To heueriche blisse
To-day ȝe shulen wende;
And þe at our sede, to sorinesse
And to suche þesternesse,
And þer ben euere, bouten ende."
He seiþ þenne to þe wreche,
"Ȝe nolden nout hof me recche;
For hounger ich aswal þroute:
Ȝe nolden me in fecche,
Ou self ȝe weren so frecche,
So modi and so proude."
Hoe gredeþ þenne on heye,
Þe wrecches and þe ounweye
Þat loueden þe ounredes,
And siggeþ, "louerd, wiþ oure eye
We þe neuere ne seye
Þer þou nede heuedest."
God seyþ, "ȝu se mine
Povere ounhole hine
Þat to oure dore come:
For chele hoe heueden pine,
For hounger hoe gonnen chine;
Þer-of ne nome ȝe gome;
"Þer-of ȝe nolden hede,
Ne ȝeuen hem of oure brede,
Ne of drinke ne of cloþe:
To-day ȝe sulen frede,
And ounder-fongen mede,
For, me ȝe be wel loþe."
Hoe ȝerreþ þenne and gredeþ;
Þe fendes hem forþ ledeþ,
Boþe licome and soule,
Seþeþ hem, and gredeþ,
Stikeþ hem and bredeþ
Wiþ pikes and wiþ howeles.
Þe soule seyþ to onsuare,
"Licom, al þou forfare
So wrechede and so ounlede,
Wor þou ous hauest .I.-wrout þis fare,
And .I.-brout ous ewche kare
Þat euere we shulen þolie.
"AtFor Ac þe gode and þe clene,
Þan hoe .I.-seien ous þenne,
Al þat cun þat we of come,
Nulle hoe neuer ene
Birewen ne bimene,
Ne þar-to nimen gome.
"Hem self, hoe beþ so bliþe
Þat hoe of wone siþe
Moten ane day wonie,
And þonkeþ god swiþe
Ofte and monie siþe,
Þat hy hit mosten herie."
AtFor Ac ȝif we ous wolden vel diȝtte,
And leden ous mid riȝtte
Þe wiles þat we her were,
Ich ou sugge and pliȝtte,
At þe domes ȝe miȝtte
Ben englene fere.
AtFor Ac bidde we oure driȝtte,
Þat dayes sop and niȝtte
Þat do hour soule bote,
So þat we miȝtte
.I.-seiene ben at siȝtte
Among þe hengles briȝtte:
Amen, so hit be mote! Amen!

DIV3.HEAD: 8. Coment le santex noustre dame fu primes cuntxoue.Printed by Horstmann, Altenglische Legenden, 1881, p. 220 seq.

LG.L: Leuedi swete and milde,
For loue of þine childe
Þat is foul of miȝtte,
Me þat am to wilde,
From shome þou me shilde
Bi day and eke bi niȝtte!
Ich wille biginnen here,
And tellen þe manere,
Nou at þisse stounde,
Of þi sauter here,
Mid wel gode chere,
Ou hit wes .I.-founde.
Send me þine grace,
Nou in þisse place
So wel for to done;
Ich nou bidde þi grace,
And þer-to lif and space;
Here nou mine bone!
Ariche man was wile,
Þat nolde none gile;
He louede holi chirche;
Bi sides him a mile,
On abbey of seint gile,
His helderne gonne werche.
God lif þis man ladde;
One sone he hadde,
Þat gode dedes dede;
Wiþ cloþ and wiþ bedde,
His sone faire he sredde
In þat ilke stede.
Monk he þere bicom,
Wiþ abit he þer nom
Bi his fader wille.
Him louede god and mon,
So faire he bigon,
Wor euere he wes stille.
His fader him bimenede
Þat he þer-inne wende,
So ȝong sholde .I.-wis.
He dede after him sende,
Þat is nou þat ende,
And made him muchel blis.
A maister hadde his sone,
Þat wiþ him wes .I.-come,
Cointe .I.-nou and sley;
Hit wes his .I.-wone,
To techen alle and some
Þe ordre fer and ney.
He hede ofte aboute,
Wiþ-innen and wiþ-oute,
Wiþ þe louerd on day;
Þe sone he lek þer oute,
He hede for to aloute;
Tellen ich ou may.
Þe leuedi ful of miȝtte,
Þat bar oure driȝtte,
In a chapele þere,
Bi day and eke bi niȝtte,
Out when he comen miȝtte,
Were ware he were.
Ou alle ich telle may,
On houndred, ewche day,
He gretingges seyde;
Wel he held his lay,
And þe ordre, bi mi fay,
For loue of þat meyde.
Wel he hedde bi-wrout,
Wor god wes his þout,
Þat wes wel .I.-sene;
He ne les hit nohut,
Wor he hit hadde about;
Þeron his gode bene.
Ne let he none stounde
Þat he ne fel to grounde,
And on kne was bat,
And þoute of þe wonde
Þat god for al þe mounde
On rode heuede .I.-sprad.
On houndret, to þe meyde,
Aue maries he seyde,
Bi tale heche daye,
Ne hit nout ne aleyde;
Ac so wel he pleyde,
Riȝt soþ for to saye,
Þat he sau wel briȝtte,
Oure leuedi foul of miȝtte,
A settres-day .I.-wis,
Were hoe sat wel riȝtte,
.I.-cloþed half bi siȝtte,
And seyde to him þis:
"Mi monk, ne dred þe nout,
For .I. þe haue .I.-bout,
And þe ich wille take;
Þou hauest so goed-ful wraut,
Ne worst þou nout bikaut;
Goed ne shal þe lake.
"Ich þonke þe her nouþe,
Þat þou, wiþ þine mouþe,
Me hauest .I.-paied wel;

Bi norþe and eke bi [souþe]The right lower corner of the MS. has come unpasted, and has fallen off. The words are supplied from the Auchinleck MS. in A Penniworth of Witte, Abbotsford Club, ed. D. Laing, and Altenglische Legenden, 1881, p. 221-3.
Hit shal ben w[el (i)couþe]
Þine dedes [euerich del].
"Ac þou m[ost more say]
Wor[me now euche day]
Fifti al bi score
Of aue maries,
Fifti on day þries,
Wite nou were-fore.
"Þat is riȝt mi sauter,
And þou shalt witen her,
Hou hit shal ben do:
Fifty sege bi-fore,
Tene euere bi score,
And on anteme þerto,
"In tokning of þe blisse
Þat fel me mid i-wisse
Þo þe aungele to me com,
And seyde me tidinge,
Þat of me sholde springe
He þat is god and mon.
"After, say wel sone,
Fifti mid idone,
Al for þat ilke blisse
Þat he wiþ-outen [sore]Corner of the MS. gone.
Wolde of me ben [bore]
Þat þou þer [of ne misse]
"Þer-aft[er þou shalt say]
Eft [fifti euche day]
Bi [þine fingres ten]
O[f aue maries]
[Euche day þries]
[Telle hit fele men!]
["Fifti at þen ende,]
[For I shude wende]
[To mi sone þo,]
[For blis and for to amende,]
[Þat he to me gan sende]
To me comen and go.
"He broute me to blisse,
Þat neuer ne shal misse,
In þat ilke stounde.
Blesced be þat time,
Þat alle brovte of pine,
Þat weren þerinne .I.-bounde!"
"A, leuedi, .I. þe grete,
For þou art fair and swete,
And goed to serui wel;
Graunte me þin ore,
Wor .I. shal euere more
Don þis euerich del.
"If ich dourste and couþe,
Ich wolde .I.-witen nouþe,
Leuedi, here of þe,
Wi þe failleþ gore,
Sleue, and nammore
Of cloþ þat ich .I.-se."
"Þis cloþ þou me ȝeue
Corner of the MS. gone.[On Se]ttresday aȝein eue,
[Þorou] Aue maries.
[Þo þou] me gvnne greten,
[And nolde] to sugen leten
[Twies e]wche dayes.
["For þou most say more]
[Þries fifti bi score,]
[Al-so .I. teld þe,]
[To-day a seveniȝtte]
[.I.-clothed al ariȝtte]
[Þou shalt me fair .I.-se]
["Be here of al scille,]
[And say wiþ gode wille]
Alle þe gretinges;
And I shal þe bringe
From mi sone, þe kinge,
Þanne gode tidinges."
Marie wente away,
And þe monke euche day
Seyde, riȝt þre siþes,
Mid wel gode wille,
Boþe loude and stille
Þese Aue maries.
Þat day a seveniȝtte,
Oure leuedi foul of miȝtte
To þat moneke com,
.I.-cloþed swiþe briȝtte
In þat wede al riȝtte,
And þonkede þat mon:
"Fair is, lo, mi wede,
For bedes þat þou bede,
And þou hauest quemet me:
Mi sone þe wille rede,
Þat noþing þe nadrede,
Here ich hit telle þe.
"Vuene þou art home .I.-come,
Þou shalt Abbot bicome,
For þin Abbot shal deye.
Haue euere in þi wone
To suggen mi coustome,
Þine Aues euche daye.
"Wend ouer al aboute
[A]nd preche inne and oute
[Þat] þis is mi sauter;
[For al] þat euche day
[Wille þis] for me saye,
I shal hem ben wel ner.
"Monek, ich telle hit þe,
Þat þou most, al for me,
Wenden wide wore,
And telle þis tidinge,
And mine sone bringe
Wel fele him bifore.
"Wor þoru Aue maries
Þat mon shal sayen þries
In þe worshipe of me,
I shal hem helpen alle
Þat to me wilen kalle,
For soþ ich telle hit þe.
"Nis non þat shal deien,
Þat wille þries seien
Þese Aue maries,
Wiþ-outen hosel and srifte,
Bi daye ne bi niȝtte,
Wor none folies;
"He shal in euche place
Wel finden mi grace
At his liues ende;
And he shal hauen space,
And finden godes grace,
Him al to amende.
"Gon ich wille henne:
Sey hit to mani menne
Þis, and make hit couþ,
Wor seue ȝer after þis
Þou shalt deye .I.-wis,
Ich telle hit þe wiþ mouþe,
"So longe is þi time
To holden þe and þine,
And hem for to teche;
After þat, of pine
Þou worst .I.-brout wiþ mine,
Wor .I. shal ben þi leche.'
Marie wente away;
Þe monek rod niȝt and day,
Folk to gode bringe;
Þoru þis ilke þinge
And þoru his prechinge,
Goed wes þe tidinge.
Nou ich bidde here
Ou alle wiþ godes chere
Þat ȝe suggen þries,
Wiþ wel gode wille,
Boþe loude and stille
Þese Aue maries.(Les ounsse peines de enfer follow, which Stengel printed in his Catalog of this MS.)

DIV3.HEAD: A Confession of Sins, and a Prayer to Christ.From a cut-down leaf of a late 14th-century MS., sent by the Rev. J. R. Burton, Headmaster of Kidderminster Grammar School, to the Deputy-Keeper of MSS. at the British Museum, Mr. G. F. Warner, who kindly showd it to me, and got Mr. Burton's leave for me to copy and print it.

LG.L: Swete ihesu crist, to þe,
Copable wrecche ich ȝelde me,
Of sennes þat ich habbe ydo
Yn al my lyue hider-to,
In pride, yn wraþþe, in vyl enuye,
Yn glotonye, yn lecherye,
Yn sleuþe, lord, yn þy seruyse,
And of þis wordles coueytise:
To ofte ich habbe, yn myne lyue,
Ysenȝed wit my wittes fyue,
Wit eren yhered, wit eȝen syȝt,
Wit senfol speche dey & nyȝt,
Wit cleppinges, wit kessenge also,
Wit hondes yhandled, wit fet ygwo,
Wit herte senfolliche yþoȝt,
Wit al my body euele y wroȝt;
And of al my [grete] folye,
Mercy, lord, mercy, ich crye!
Al-þaȝ ich senȝede euere,
Lord, ich for-soc þe neuere.
Ȝef þou me none med[e]
Efter my senful dede, [. . . . .]
Ak efter, lord, þy grete [pite],[back]
Lord ihesu, asoyle þou me,
And send me ofte, er [y deye],
Sorȝe of herte and teres o[f eȝe]
For sennes þat ich habbe [ido]
Yn al my lyue hider[to];
And let me neuere b[e so nice]
To do no maner dede [of vice],
So þat ich, at myn end[yng day]
Clene of senne deye [may],
Srifte and housele at [myn ende],
Þat my saule mote [wende]
Yn-to þat blisse of [hevenriche]

Þer þou regnest, lo[rd, ].[Two lines are no doubt left out after l. 22: the sense wants, 'If thou rewardest me according to my sinful deeds, I must go to hell,' or some equivalent words to make a couplet.]
